phyſitian maieſtie highneſſe professor anatomy chyrurgerie publiſhed king maieſties eſpeciall direction warrant according firſt integrity originally written avthor —etiam parnaſsia laurus parua ſubingentimatris ſe ſubijcit vmbra printed william iaggard dwelling barbican ſold 1615 serenissimo potentissimo liter atiſsimo que principi ac domino noſtro iacobo dei gratia magnae britanniae franciae hiberniae regi fidei defenſori c vt ſuſcepti mole operis cui vix cuiuſuis noſtrorum hominum vires reſpondent inaſſueta ſcriptioni manus merito dum rem pararem deteruêre quo minus auguſto tuo nomini inſcriptam vellem rex ſereniſſime tui ſeculi longe literatiſſime ita demum conſcientia animi integri ſed quorundam quos minime decuit obtrectatione tentati ad eam impulit rectê factorum fiduciam vt primum libenter ad tuam maieſtatem prouocauerim quem faelicitas publica cum primis literaria non orbis modo noſtri ſed 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 imperio admouit enimuero vt taceam eam quam exterae gens tuis egregiè ſcriptis amant admirantur 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 interior illa 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 quam ante annos aliquot altera nouiſſimè cantabrigienſi academia publiciſ que comitijs ſub tuis auſpicijs habitis ſignatam exhibuit maieſtas tua non finit dubitare litem hanc de literaria tuo tribunali ordinariè competituram duo igitur ſunt quae huic operi affigunt ſi non affingunt crimina mihi ipſi tertium primum id que maximum nefas eſſe ducunt artis myſteria ignobili vulgo proſtituiſſe secundum velamen naturae reuelare pudititiam quaſi propatulo ponere tertium illiberalis eſſe ingenij arguunt aliena quercu lignari quae ſingula quidē amoliri vt mea plurimum intereſſe ſentio ita ſupplex obteſtor maieſtatem tuam pro eo quo coronatae incedunt virtutes tuae candore vt tantiſper tua tempora demorer dum totidē momentis molumenta iſthaec diruam que primum mouit non modo ſcriptorum veterum graecorum latinorum arabum recepta conſuetudo qui ad vnum omnes artes quif que ſuas cuiuſuis generis indigitarunt fed neotericorum ſchola medicorum qui patrio idiomate vel primum donarunt inventa anatomica vel poſtea traduxerunt cuius reilocuples mihi teſtis eſt par quae que europae maxime literata hiſpaniam dico gallia italiam vtram que germaniam ne que vero noſtra anglia ſiluit haec muſa aut poſtliminio tantum recepta eſt ſed ſuperiori ſeculo nata ſub patre filio filia potentiſſimis literatiſſimis principibus ter quidem inſtaurata ſed deſtituta fomentis cunis adhuc vagire deprehenditur ſiquidem vt vrbium imperiorum que ita literarum ſua ſunt lenta tempora quibus oriuntur florent ſeneſcunt tandem intereunt taceo illa maximum quidem ſed commemorata nobis libro primo rationum momentum quibus ab vtilitate voluptate neceſſitate ipſa quotquot mortalium ſumus cogimur trahimur allicimur communionem naturalis sacramenti ſummae magni opificis ſapientiae bonitatis quis os erecta dedit oculos verſicolores quis narium perforationes ſinuoſas aurium tornauit cochlea quis venarum arteriarum que riuos aquaeductus diſtribuit neruorum tetendit rigiditates oſſium 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 poſuit cutis effloreſcentiam membranarum expanſa dilatauit quis artus artuum que digitos diviſit firmauit pes poros ſpiracula terebrauit quis excavavit pulmonum broncho ſpirituſ que reciprocationes inſtituit quis motus cordis geminos intermediam quietem concluſae vitae ſubſultationes pulſuſ que limitavit quis viſcerum coagulavit conglomerata parenchymata quis senſuum 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 animae regiam ſtipavit cerebrum falce diviſit arcuatam concamerationem medulla ſpeculum que lucidum diſpoſuit quis ſpirituum animalium diſterminauit conceptacula reticulum mirable plexum que choroidem innexvit dy deficeret ſi ventriculus chyloſin inteſtinorum volumina meſaraicarum ſuctus hepatis ſanguificationem anaſtomoſes mirabiles ſi lienis defaecationem renum emulctus veſicarum collectiones teſtium irradiationes vteri ſenſus mille artes naturae minimis particulis ingenitas praedicem quae ſi non ſingula praecipua tamen nouiſſe cuius deus bone non intererit circumgerimus ignota miracula ſectamur quiſquilias extra no querentes dum domi perigrinamur obſignata inquiunt myſteria arti reverentiam artifici dignitatem pariunt scilicet ſemper mo fuit hominum vel illiteratorum vel queſtui inhiantium religiones arteſ que tanquam ſcrinio concluſas gerere nevel foedae argui poſſint inſcitiae vel emolumenti tantillum ſibi detrahi ſinant quanquam ſilegitima virtutis praemia ſpectent non aliunde cumulatius noſtri ordinis hominibus ſubminiſtrari ſentiant quam ab ijs qui vel leuiter initiati vanos etiam metus expaueſcunt vel altius inſtituti fidam artem vt agnoſcunt ita cum opus eſt expoſcunt amplectuntur sed ſi ne que veterum calcare viam nec recentium laudabili inſtituto inſiſtere velint vt illorum obſe qui poſſint voluntati quos vel diuerſa ſtudia vel occupationes literis alienae minus idoneos rediderunt qui rigidam anatomicorum orationem percipiant certe juventuti chyrurgicae ne invideant qui cum de noſtra repub colonia ſint equum eſt ea leges ea jura teneant quibus ſibi decori nobis dum re eſt vſui eſſe poſſint qui idcirco non ingenio stromatico inſtituendi aut cothurnatis ciſſionijſ que crepidis induendi ſed per genuina artis praecepta facili methodo deducendi vt quae domi vel ſuo marte tēporum injuria vix conſequi poſſunt noſtra opera ſibi abundè ſuppeditata cognoſcant ea que ita mitigata vt poſſint concoqui ne que enim vbiuis terrarum doctores medici adſunt aut cuiuſvis fortunae eſt ſtipendium medicum numerare igitur neceſſum habeant perire eos omnes quorum vel re anguſta vel habitatio medicorum frequentia ſecluſa eſt ſaltem ſecreta naturae reuelanda non ſunt ne que auribus oculiſue obijcienda quae male feriatorum mentes paſcant incendant veniunt hic mihi primo loco repetenda quae dudum adduxi de conſilio omnium seculorum nationum hominum quorum nemo harum partium hiſtoriam detrectauerit de admiranda diuini creatoris ijſdem partibus ſapientia de adminiſtration circa eaſdem neceſſitate quae eo magi vrgere ſoleat quo ſymptomata plerum que inducunt vt grauiora triſtiora ita maxime frequentia quid quod scriptura sacrum rachaelis menſes puerpearum profluvia carnis ſaliuationem gonorrhoea ſemen concubitus sarae 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 quam admodum violenter inquit stephanus ſeminis conceptionem pro emiſſione interpretantur deſcribere non erubuit quid quod ipſi publicis diſſectionibus non delineatas imago ſed ipſum corpus humanum vtriuſ que ſexus ſpectandum palpandum que exhibent parteſ que obſcoenas ſecant reſecant que corona populi patrio idiomate ſingula explicant quo minus alteri vitio vertant quae ſibi laudi ducunt tribuendum eſt aliquid pudicitiae certe quidem no non parum tribuimus quoad fieri potuit non neglecta quae ſub manibus erat honeſtis circumlocutionibus argumentum molle exaſperatum reddimus vbi propoſito inſiſtendum erat philoſophica diſputatione lectoris mentem diuerſum trahimus ne vatinoceat mala lingua futuro icones ſunt pluſquam aretinae ita theatro anatomico publicè ad invidiam conciliandam nuperrime nominibantur quae non aliae quam quae noſtro hoc ſeculo centies impreſſae vbi que terrarum circumferuntur pij principibus rebuſpub approbatae non aliae quam quae virgini caſtiſſimae elizabethae ſacroſanctae memoriae principi dedicatae manus traditae ſunt crimine ab vno diſce omnes frontem triſti cenſura ſtriatam dein que dignitatem mihi exprobant academicam quod aliorum veſtigijs inſiſtens de alieno prodigus de proprio parcus fuerim ne que ſane diffitebor ſanguinem ſuccum que hauſiſſe ex alijs methodum limen limam que noſtra voco ſuper quae ſaepenumero diſquiſitionibus occurrunt partes meas addidi etiam plurimorum anatomicorum 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſuffragia retractationes demonſtrationes 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 quae omnia vel colligere vel collecta repetere vnde deſumpta ſunt ſuis quae que locis diſponere non nudi eſt tralatoris quanquam fuerunt inter no ſunt viri valde docti quorum diuina ingenia longeſequor veſtigia ſemper adoro quibus transferendi munus faſtidio non fuit —etiam parnaſsia laurus parua ſub ingenti matris ſe ſubijcit vmbra ne que hoc mihi jure quis audaciae loco imputauerit ſi remigem prius eſſe velim quam ad gubernacula manus admouerim ne que ſocordiae ſi proprio vtar remigio que niſi ego fallor ſi quis hoc curriculo mecum deſudauerit pedem pedi contulerit ſentiet profecto ſe 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ita praecipitijs praeruptis anfractibus totus hic ager ſcatet mitto viſcerum viam perplexam ſpinis obſitam quae tot artis proceres colliſit quas vaſorum conjugationes quae diuortia quam implicitas divaricationes rimari ſequi ſuos alueos deducere oportet muſculorum nomina origines progreſſus implantationes subſtructorum oſſium appendix proceſſus perforationes ſuturae harmoniae gomphoſes diarthroſes ſynarthroſes enarthroſes arthroidae ginglymoi eorundem ſynchondroſis ſynſarcoſis ſyndeſmoſis mille tedia ſuperanda ſunt immenſū aequor arandum antequam fugientem oram prehenderis neigitur mihi fraudi ſit eaſdem horas ſtudijs inſumere publicae vtilitati conſecrare quas alij qui magnae potius quam bonae famae ſunt inter globulos fumum prolixe diſperdunt artem tracto tentatam quidem ante ſed ſubſultim leui pede ab ijs quorum voluntates probaveris potius quam facultates qui tamen cum primum ad vexillum fuerunt merito ſuo primipili audient noſtro opere fidem invenies indefeſſam diligentiam orationem non illam quidem ornatam qui poteram abruptare ſed evidentem dilucidam verborum etiam delectum ſed non tam quae delectent quam quae inſtruant quamquam ipſa artis vocabula adiunximus ſed reddita vt apud lector ſeipſum apud alios iſtos ipſos intelligat que hactenus conſilij mei rationem ita vt teneor expoſui quod vt majeſtatis tuae bona cum venia ſit humillimè obnixè contendo faueas primitijs creſcentis indolis quae ſi sub tuo sole adoleverit iuſtam tandem world altogether naked vnarmed vniuſtly nature called ſowre ſtepdame man ſoule man naked ſoule bodie therefore holde bee creature moſt imperfect nakedneſſe soule thus diſcourſe creature ſay perceyue vnderſtand owne nature ſome betake themſelues ſwiftneſſe feete ſome truſt loftineſſe flight ſome ſwimme water man knoweth nothing neyther ſpeake goe feede word creature borne rule gouerne reſt wanting may giue ſatisfaction ſuch deſire inquire principall part worthily preferred aboue reſt galen firſt booke de ſemine preferreth teſticles heart ſaith heart indeede author liuing testicle galen preferreth teſticles heart adde betterneſſe farther degree perfection life becauſe taken away iollity courage creature extinguiſhed male followeth female veynes looſe latitude become ſunke narrow pulſe abateth ſtrength becomes weake dull languiſhing skin pilde bare whereupon ſuch men called glabriones word virility glabriones galen manhoode vaniſheth away galen addeth teſticles another fountaine wellſpring inbred heate feuplace firehearth lares houſholdgods body ſolace diſport themſelues hence whole body receyueth wherein teſticles ſhew power encreaſe heate meanes onely foecundity alſo great alteration temper habite proper ſubſtance yea manner themſelues ſo ſay true power great almoſt incredible eſpecially knowne wanting may obſerue eunuch wherefore liue well excellent ſimply liue haue idle ſluggiſh exiſtence ſo inſtrument former teſticles excellent latter heart probable ſophiſticall argument galen ſubtile argument anſwered true giueth better life giue life alſo excellent giueth life onely teſticles giue life creature liue without adde indeed perfection life concreate ſay liuing abſtract ſo eye ſo part without man ſhould liue liuing ſhould miſerable heart therefore giueth ſubſtance teſticles exhibite additament may away albeit bee notable detriment detriment ſay heart giueth ſubſtance themſelues affoord complement ſubſtance excellence complement man deny heart therefore noble whether braine preferd hart teſticles heart hath greater concurrent plea honour braine peripatetikes ariſtotle prince together whole family almoſt opinion peripatetiks stoiks stoickes eſpecially chryſippus giue preheminence heart well becauſe ſeated middeſt place honour alſo becauſe liuing abundant fountaine natiue heate finally becauſe ſpeciall habitation ſoule euen hippocrates 5 chapter booke de spiratione difference ſaith hee betwixt art nature art vſeth heate onely inſtrument nature vſeth inſtrument matter fire vſed artiſt worke part worke ſelfe heate nature diffuſed thorough ſubſtance ſhe intendeth accompliſh learned men make twofold kinde inſtrument wherewith wherein inſtrument wherewith remaineth part formed wherein remaineth ſubiect forming faculty otherwiſe skinne vapour thicke paſſage leaueth ſome part ſelfe wit groſſeſt outlet impacted ſucceeding vapour ariſing whēce former protruded thruſt forward ſo manner production compariſon one vapour continually ſolliciting vrging another wrought together one body euen chimneyes ſee continuall aſcent ſoote long ſtrings gathered chaine difference ſtraitneſſe paſſages skin matter haires anoyded formeth ſmall roundneſſe euen wyre receyueth proportion whereof hole drawne manner outgate matter thus continuall appulſion arriuall ſuch vapour skin pore plenarily obſtructed next vapour ſ • compa •• ſtriueth liberty ſmiteth former reaſon ſtraitneſſe paſſage driuen forme cord would ſee expreſſe image manner production let reſort glaſier extendeth mettall guttered lead wherein faſtneth glaſſe ſhall perceiue artiſt hath made engine whereby inch lead driuen foote length neceſſary therefore ſayth hippocrates booke de carnibus ſooty excrement ſhould haue hippocrates clammy glewy ſubſtance yet without fatneſſe greaſineſſe wherefore whereſoeuer body eſpecially outward part gathereth together ſuch glewy clammy excrement naturall heat bringeth forth haires cauſe armeholes priuy part yea reſt body haires growe plentifully part haire impacted pore compariſon skinne may fittely bee reſembled roote hearbe ſticking ground beareth skin hearbe ſelfe alſo required conuenient place foundation wherein rootes conueniency place hayres haires may eſtabliſhed skinne part fitteſt breading ſayth galen firſt chapter ſecond booke de temperamentis becauſe neither dry moyſt neither marriſh fenny ground one ouer dry worne heart thing bee brought forth ſo ouer moyſt ouer dry skin haire grow though skin accounted dry yet man without ſome moyſture thoſe creature couered ouer ſtony cruſty ſhell oyſters lobſters crab ſuch like ſuch lurke dry skin admitteth hayres ſort dennes snake thoſe haue ſcales fiſhes haire cannot grow becauſe skinnes truely altogether dry moreouer skin ought ſoft moyſt like cheeſe new curded would holde rootes hayre becauſe thinnes beſide pore bored excrement would fall together part ſo fluid would run one another bee exquiſitely reunited moderately dry hold haire roote moderatly dry thin moderately hard vnlike cheeſe already well gathered ſomewhat preſſed ſo would bee better thrilled perforated iſſuing humour perforation alſo would remaine dry body ſuffering part reunite conſiſt ſo continuall exiture matter pore would bee fiſtulated muſt alſo ſlack thinne wherefore conſidering whole skin full pore whereout ſomthing continually breathed naturall heate diſperſeth attenuateth carrieth away ſelfe ſmall part inward moyſture followeth part body haires may iſſue forth euery pore hauing haire keepe open better breathing thruſting exhalation yet muſt except skin palm ſoales hand foot becauſe ſome ſay thē large tendon immediatly vnder skin exceeding thicke dry make vncapable haires cannot admitte reaſon ſeeing hare hath alſo broad tendon yet haue palmes ſoales haires grow vppon ſcars 2 kind haires ariſt 3 hiſt animal 11 congeniti hath thoſe part voyde haire therefore wee ſay nature hath made thoſe partes haireleſſe vſe might ſenſible alſo ſome 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 congeniti bred v haire head eyebrowes eyelid theſe bred child yet wombe reſembled vnto hearbes grow ſowing vnto ſuch plant nature bringeth forth owne accord ſuch neceſſarily follow temperature body haires called 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 poſtgeniti bred skin growne thin poſtgeniti hapneth boyes beginne breed ſeede girles monthly courſes begin flow theſe come three place anſwerable three place nature bringeth forth former kinde firſt priuities ſecondly vnder arme hole thirdly chin cheekes thoſe gelded age foureteen haires fall ſuch gelded yeares haue haires growing chinne reaſon becauſe wayes ſeede opened caſtration intercepted therefore skinne doth rarifie thoſe haires growne teſticles taken away thoſe haires alſo fall excepting groyne againe woman thoſe hayres wee called poſtgeniti doe ariſe later neuer chinne becauſe ſo great agitation humor act generation woman rarifie skin ſo farre place ſeed engendred yet wee ſee ſome woman courſes ſtaide woman haue berds haire begin bud chin may alſo fall men woman may without postgeniti ſome naturall deſect contracted generation forme haires expreſſed certaine accident vary thickeneſſe thinneſſe hardneſſe whiteneſſe blackneſſe middle colour betweene ſo alſo reaſon age growth body chiefe cauſe thickneſſe thinneſſe skin ſaith ariſtotle 5 gener animal j ſome thicke others thin ſome rare cauſes craſsitude others thight compact another cauſe variety moiſture lying vnder skin ſome clammy others wateriſh ſo thicke skin thick hard haire thin skin thin ſlender haires produced skin rare thicke haires alſo thicke reaſon abundance earthly ſubſtance laxity paſſages skin thight compact though thicke come thin reaſon narrowneſſe paſſages vapour whereof bred wateriſh becauſe quickly dryed vppe growe much length bee clammy glutinous becauſe eaſily dried vp ſpread themſelues length cauſe length ſhortneſſe haires abundance ſcarſity humor wherewith fed hence haires head longeſt bodie becauſe braine lēgth haires head longeſt affoordeth great deale clammy moyſture becauſe braine bigger glandules alſo craſſe thicke becauſe skin head exceeding thicke yet rare containing much moiſture haires head latine called capilli quiſi capitis pili greeke 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſignifieth cut men name haires head called caeſaries à frequēti caeſione becauſe often cut woman coma becauſe beſtow great paine combing curling alſo woemen diuided line greeke called 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 latine diſcrimen engliſh ſhed haire either ſtraight curled eyther reaſon exhalation ſelfe pore whereout paſſe exhalation vvhich ſmoaky cauſes ſtrcitneſſe cuiling haire heate drought maketh haire curled hath double courſe earthy dry part downeward hot part vpwarde hence boweth downe right wrinkingly becauſe little moiſture much dry earthy matter may perceiue parch haires sun neare fire criſping haire kinde convulſion becauſe wanteth moiſture elſe may ſay haire curleth reaſon drineſſe temper therefore blackmoores haue curled criſped haire reaſon conſtitution pore wherein implanted exhalation ſo weake cannot make ſtraight way ſelfe curling giueth forme pore anſwereable owne contortion exhalation bee ſtrong enough yet cannot aſcend directly vpwardes reaſon hardneſſe compariſon skin turneth ſidelong like ſee ſmoake flame hindred mount ſtreight vpwards diuideth ſelfe turnes aſlant wherefore reaſon imbecility exhalation hardneſſe skin root haires grow awry ſtandeth good reaſon ſhould growe continue ſtill ſuch framed roote hard dry body extended ſtreight forth vnleſſe firſt ſoftned mollified thoſe haue aboundance moiſture pore ſtreight haue haire alſo ſtreight againe long haires ſoft curled hard moreouer haires encreaſe ſtreight haires grow leſſe according nature skin equall magnitude ſeldome fall becauſe haue vnder hard body like vnto griſtle thoſe haires ſpring ſoft moderately moyſt part encreaſe much thoſe head beard galen addeth thoſe armepits priuities thoſe ariſe hard dry place ſmall almoſt growth yet ſome eyebrowes grow ſo hairy olde age conſtrained cut elſe would offend eye haire buddeth chin skin beginneth rarifie beard grow thin matter moyſture ſent thither head hippocrates holdeth booke de natura pueri theſe haires make beard alike euery man ſome chin lip haue great ſtore haire ſome haue haire much cheekes ariſtotle third booke de hiſtor animal 11 chapter ſaith haires vſe grow extraordinarily ſome diſeaſes eſpecially conſumptions hee addeth alſo old body dead corpes receiue augmentation length thickneſſe ſpring anew varie likewiſe colour anſwerable predominant humor ſuch cauſes colour haires hippocrates de nat pueri humour galen black reddiſh white humor fleſh draweth vnto ſaith hippocrates ſuch alſo colour haire galen ſecond booke de temperamentis fift chapter ſaith haire becomes blacke vaporous excrement ſcorched heate changed perfect ſoote ſomewhat red excrement impacted paſſage yet altogether growne black yellow vapour leſſe ſcorched excrement ſo impacted proceedeth yellow blacke choller white haires made flegme colour betwixt theſe mixture flegme choller queſtion may asked beaſtes colour haire followeth colour skinne men far otherwiſe far whiteſt men woman haue often men haires colour skin haire coale blacke ariſtotle maketh anſwere 5 de generatione animal 3 3 histor 11 becauſe ſayth hee man skin thinner skin creature magnitude therefore skinne cannot affoord matter haire ſelfe reteyne excrement driuen ſo long giue owne colour haire varyeth alſo reaſon region diuerſe diſpoſitions ambient ayre ſo thoſe inhabite hotte dry country haue hard blacke dry curled region brittle haire ſmall growth egyptian arabian indian contrariwiſe thoſe inhabit moyſt cold climate haue ſoft haires grow moderatly ſmall fine ſtraight reddiſh illirians german sarmatians coaſt scythia galen ſayth ſuch inhabit temperate tract betweene theſe haue hayre greater growth exceeding ſtrong ſomewhat blacke moderately thicke neither altogether curled altogether ſtraight vary alſo reaſon age little child haue little haire becauſe yet skin hath pore ſootie excrement applying vnto beginne haires alter acording age cotten xii xiiii yeares age haires ſmall weake youth growes ſtrong flouriſhes grow vpon towards xv xviii haires grow many great ſtrong well becauſe skin growne full pore alſo abound ſootie excrement thoſe well yeares haue hard haire becauſe skin becomes hard thicke old age reaſon coldneſſe ſiccity ſee ſome men grow yeares become bald eyther want hot clammy moiſture becauſe naturally originally skin ſomewhat dry eunuch child vſe growe balde baldneſſe begin commonly forepart head becauſe ſaieth ariſtotle 5 generat animal 3 dryeſt skin lyeth vpon bare bone without interpoſition fat nowle like manner men growing olde become grayheaded reaſon drought ſee often many haires become gray together nothing vpon ſuddaine old men grow gray become dry true cauſe putrifaction want ventilation therefore thoſe haue head continually couered grow ſooner hoary others ariſtotle obſerued galen ſecond booke de temperam 5 chapter ſaith 3 hiſt▪ animal skin head growne extreame drineſſe haires become weak want conuenient foode white becauſe nouriſhment wherewith fed dregges flegme proceſſe time remaining skin putrifie part temple firſt hairy becauſe moyſt reaſon great muſcles lye vnder euery muſcle fleſhy fleſh cannot ſee reade vpon booke layd vpon eye becauſe wanteth meane betweene obiect inſtrument ſenſe ayre enlightned like manner cuticle cannot diſtinguiſh one temper another becauſe gentleſt touch bared ſtretch exquiſite ſence thicker membrane ingendred ſubſtance ſeede perfectly mixed bloud whence commeth paſſe wee may iudge well ſpermaticall bloudy part ſeemeth therefore middle nature betwixt fleſh ſinew ſo veſalius conceiued ſo abounding whereof made veſalius galen bloud fleſh bloudy ſinew ſo ſayth galen firſt booke de temperam notwithſtanding compoſition ſpermatical part exceedeth ſanguine conſtringed writhen fleſh vnder reaſon hayres grow vppon ſcarres becauſe haue foundation true skinne hath ſhould ſeeme heerein galen plato aristotle ſomewhat miſtaken skinne may flayed plato ariſtotle fleſh vnder yea betweene skin fleſh two partes leaſt may ſo called fat fleſhy membrane skin naturally white according humour abound bodyes vnder ſaith hippocrates booke de ſuccis varieth colour example colour followeth humor blood aboundeth skin thin face roſie redneſſe mingleth ſelfe white ouercommeth eſpecially eyther heate motion minde flowe place plentifully blood condenſed thickned cold maketh skin looke liuid blew chollericke men skin pallid yellowiſh melancholy ſwarty blackiſh duskiſh bee defiled vitiated humor becommeth yellow black iaundiſe morphew altereth alſo colour reaſon body vnder ſo adhereth cleaueth fleſh bals cheekes palmes handes ſooner becommeth red fat whiter ſmoother eſpecially fat plentifull fat conſumed skin becommeth wrinkled looketh like duskiſh ſhadow alſo liuid blewiſh greater veines branched vnder furthermore skin might kinde muniment defence thicke though ſo thicke creature cannot without extreame paine bee ſeparated fleſh becauſe extreamities end veſſels determine whence ſome haue thought proceedeth thoſe extreamities veſſels dilated ſpread ſuperficies ſmooth plainneſſe ſoft exquiſite ſenſe forewarneth inward part approaching euill ouertake according diuers vſe part either ſofter thinner face yard ſcrotum cod harder necke backe leg ſoles part skin thin thick feete ſome middle temper betweene hard ſoft palme hand eſpecially finger end becauſe ordained apprehend beſide skin hand power ſenſe feeling perfect therefore behooued ſhould bee voide exceſſe moſt temperate others becauſe iudge feeling inſtruments muſt free forreigne externall quality whereby iudgement might preiudiced ſome part skin exceeding thicke head ſome part onely thicke necke ſome part thin ſides ſoales feete reaſon men tickliſh ſome part yet thinner palme hand ſome thinneſt lippes hath alſo diuers connexion diuers part ſomewhere may bee eaſily ſeparated vpper middle venter armes legges otherwhere hardly connexion skin becauſe fleſhy membrane tied mediation certaine fibre veſſels betweene ſaide membrane fat ſo interpoſeth ſelfe skin may eaſily flayed ſome part hardly ſeparated ſoales feete palmes hand fat interpoſeth maketh skin eaſie flay immediately conioyned apprehenſion thoſe part may firme ſtable alſo hardly ſeparated fleſh forehead almoſt whole face eſpecially eares lippes becauſe tendon muſcles eſpecially call broad aboundant like pinhoales ſyue ſearce manifeſt pore ſweate hayre breathes breakes regard plato compare fiſh net theſe part way tranſpiration excrement third concoction haue might way haue egreſſe auoydance whence ſome tranſpiration called vniuerſall emunctorie draught becauſe receiueth ſuperſluities inward part theſe pore ſmall almoſt inſenſible leaſt otherwiſe ſhould free diſsipation ſpirits yet ſome body narrower ſtreighter ſome wider ſuch doe eaſily melt away ſweat leſſe affected inward cauſes ſweat difficultly becauſe excrement retayned doe eaſily incurre diſeaſes thereby theſe pore may bee kept open nature hath aſsigned euery one haire haires ſet cuticle bāds tyes deligatories part become bloudy ſhall ſpeake faſtned pore ſlimy white roote excepting thoſe place continually worne palmes handes theſe pore cauſe band ſome deligations become bloudy ſometime pure bloud hath auoided engliſh ſweate theſe alſo ſome thinke ſpirits doe powre themſelues forth profuſe ioy liberall vſe saffron diaphoreticke ſweating medicine exceedingly relaxed skinne may nouriſhed may liue haue ſence receiueth theſe three common organ inſtruments nouriſhment life ſence veines artery ſinewes whoſe diuarications diuers branching wee ſhall ſhew fitter place diſcourſe veſſels vſes skin firſt ſhould bee immediate inſtrument outward touching might forewarned outward iniuries come hurt inward partes muſcles entrals contayned proper place defended heate colde naturall heate deteined ouer free effluxion chap vii fat fat called greeke 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 latin pinguedo man bedded betwixt fat wher ingendred skinne fleſhy membrane beaſtes vnder membrane alſo ingendered oylie thinne ayrie portion pure abſolutely laboured concocted bloud diſtilling like dew ſmal capillarie veines habite body bloude curdled moderate heate burning heate would conſume weake heat would concoct denſity faſtnes membrane reaſon beaſtes grow fatteſt winter skin condenſed cold membrane neruous thin faſt thight vnder skin incloſeth body oylie matter rarified vapor ſlippeth inward mē branes may light vpon cleaue vnto ſo turned fat nothing profitable might loſt manner worke nature wee haue diſtillations though stilhead hot yet becauſe ſadneſſe denſity vapour rayſed vp heate fire thickned water fat man leſſe white creature yet white membrane bloud matter paſſeth alter ſomewhat ſo becommeth often yellower white ſome part alſo ſome age want fat thoſe part whoſe part age haue leaſt fat bending extenſion might annoy better without membrane braine eyebrowes yarde cod stone teſticles whereuppon ſome haue excluded number contayning inueſting part thoſe part differeth hardneſſe ſoftneſſe part mooued hard ſoft violently harder wouen fibre ſmall veines wee ſee tallow beaſtes palme hand inſide whence called neruous skin temperate fleſh fleſhy nerue ſo anotherplace fleſh bee adſtringed dryed becommeth like skinne skin dryer thighter fleſh hippocrates alſo expreſſeth ſo much ſayth outward skin continual ſelfe bloudy nerue becauſe expoſed aire hippocrater ſometimes colder ſometimes warmer often affected needes help one temper contrary may proued authority galen auicen temperate galen ſayth skin nouriſhed phlegmaticke bloud therefore temper phlegme nouriſhment part galen ſame whereof compounded auicen ſayeth fleſh commeth neerer exact equality temper part fleſh therefore skinne temperate moreouer cannot temperate weakeſt part skin receiueth ſuperfluities inward partes therefore called anſwere argumēts proue temperate vniuerſall emunctory theſe knot may eaſily cleft ſoft wedge skin nouriſhed phlegmatick bloud ful boyled labored wee know hot cold auicen ſayth fleſh moſt temperate commeth neareſt temperate ſo whole body man ſayd bee temperate although hot moyſt weakneſſe skinne proceedeth temper weake ſelfe owne nature euent reaſon ſcituation veſſels greater veſſels becauſe neerer fountaine ſtronger expelling skin weake becomes emunctory vertue innerparts powerfull whence inward partes expell ſuperfluities outward greater veſſels ſmaller veſſels habit ſo skinne becommeth weaker becauſe expelling faculty withinwarde ſtronger layeth burthen vpon skinne fleſh dryed becauſe woundes fleſh dryed degenerateth cicatrice scarre like nature skinne may bee confirmed authority aristotle galen ariſtotle auoucheth fleſh groweth old ſo turneth skinne galen skinne produced fleſh vnder becauſe fleſh skin many body interpoſed wit fat fleſhy membrane truely neruous vnleſſe neck face cannot ſee skin ſhould grow fleſh skin ſcar rather reſulteth vppon wound opinion proued falſe tanning fal away whence come hole sheep skin made parchment thinke compounded fleſh ſinewes mingled together becauſe many place galen skin called bloudy nerue prooued bee falſe one argument becauſe moſt ſtore nerues skinne harder thē palme hand nerues crown head yet skinne crown much harder palme think determination time determine skin ingendred together part wit ſeed bloud mixed together may therefore called fleſhy nerue neruous fleſh becauſe hath middle nature fleſh knew vtterly without bloud nerue ſo abounding bloud fleſh bloud appeareth argument skin made ſeede bloud euidently neuer ſo little wounded ſeed one argument may ſerue periſhed neuer bee reſtored impoſsible heale wound part skinne taken away without ſcarre cicatrice leſſe whether skin performe common officiall action qvest iiii many phyſitians haue ſame opinion vſe action skinne haue vſe action bone bone haue common common opinion official vſe ſo ſayth hippocrates giue body ſtability vprightnes figure performe common officiall action account hip lib de natu oſsium common action ſeruiceable either part whole creature like manner skinne hath indeed common vſe becauſe couereth whole body cheriſheth tyeth together thought performe officiall common action galen ſpeaketh plainely skin ſaith concocteth ſtomacke diſtributeth gut veynes breedeth bloud liuer frameth pulſation heart artcries cauſeth reſpiration lung chest mooueth voluntary motion muſcles notwithſtanding one common action may bee attributed vnto wit animall action common action skin animal although ſenſation paſsion becauſe ſenſatiue ſuffer yet ſenſation without action better learned philoſophers ſenſation doe acknowledge double motion one materiall another formall former motion ſenſation made reception ſpecies muſt craue liberty vſe schoole tearmes latter action firſt inſtrument reaſon matter latter reaſon power ſoule firſt effectuating cauſe ſenſation diſpoſition thereto latter eſſentially ſenſation itſelfe whereas therefore skinne apprehenſiue thoſe quality ſtrike mooue tactiue ſenſe thereupon eſteemed iudge diſcerner outward touching performeth vnto whole creature onely common vſe alſo common amongſt ancient phyſitians generation fat hath raiſed ſuch tempeſt art waues day ſetled needeth therefore ſome aeolus mulcere ho fluct u appeaſe theſe waues call windes abate calme time intend want promiſcuouſly vſed phyſitians albeit aristotle galen haue taken great paine diſtinguiſh euery one another place refer thoſe deſire heerein ſatisfaction onely paine ſelues temper generation fat time galen opinion fat congealed colde expreſſely declareth together fat curdled galen opinion cold manner manner vvhen aſery oyly part bloud ſweateth thin coates veines maner dew lighteth vpon colder part ſuch membrane power cold condenſed hence woman moſt part fatter men becauſe colder ſame reaſon al creature growing fatter winter time alſo thoſe woman fatter thē men haue ſmaller veſſels know ſmalnes narrowneſſe veſſels cauſed coldneſſe temper time thoſe creature haue large veſſels yet grow fat naturall aduentitious temper acquired accident wit diet order life moreouer fat congealed colde hence euident becauſe heate preſently molten liquefied lower argument proue curdled heate belly becauſe membranous farre remooued fountaine heate therefore couered ouer leafe fat ſometimes great weight part vnder breaſt haue leſſe fat philoſophy galen almoſt greeke arahian phyſitians thoſe hold contrary thus demonſtrate matter fat hot worker heat effect hot matter galen himſelfe acknowledgeth made aery fat oily part blood alſo choler ſeede therefore thoſe creature fat grow barren wee would fat thing firſt lib geld ariſtotle ſaith fat neither earthy 3 de hiſt anim 2 de partibus animal watry airy therefore floateth alwayes aboue ayre wee know hot moyſt efficient working cauſe hot aristotle firſt men prooued ſaith fat made concoction boyling onely heat coneocteth boyleth thing problemes giueth reaſon fat ill ſauour becauſe ſayth crude raw concocted opinion philoſopher doth learned veiga follow argenterius alſo laurentius ioubert ſet foorth elegant ſubtile paradoxe concerning nature fat weight principall reaſons opinion briefely wee ſet concretion made actually cold ſeene ice oyle honie ſuch like outward cold aire congealed ſuch actuall cold cā congeale fat cold liuing body bone verie hot bee touched membrane actually hot membranous ſtomacke boyle chylus membranous bladder bur • eth flegme euen ſtone autcen ſaith membrane hotter braine barine hotter moſt ſoulery hot aire heate summer summer heate melteth congealeth coldneſſe therefore membrane cannot congeale fat againe heart hotteſt inward part perpetual motion yet compaſſed baſis aboundant fat membrane braine watred aboundance blood wouen many thouſand veſſels neuer fat adhereth vnto coates bone old men melancholy perſons whoſe temper cold haue yet melancholy men ſeldo fat little fat kidneyes hot bake yea burne flegme ſtones haue yet abundance fat beſide fat liuing part bodye becauſe hath certaine definite forme figure whitened power membrane altereth euer durſt ſay liuing part man body made actuall cold may alſo add authority galen fauouring opinion hee ſaith cold dry body fat larded amidſt fleſh membranous effect fat hot coates euery one confeſſe fleſh hot finally effect teach v fat hot galen reckoneth among concocting simple fatty kall ſaith booke vſe part heate furthereth concoction ſtomack beſide eaſily taketh fire wherefore referre cauſe concretion congealing ariſtotle faſtneſſe thightneſſe membrane ſay ayery fat part bloode paſſeth eaſily rare ſpongy fleſh commeth membrane ſtayed congealed heate becommeth white operation ſpermatical part adhereth wit membrane add heereto authority hippocrates ſaith heate ſeate reſidence fat pinguis ſedem metropolim eſſe calidum thus ſee battell pitcht either ſide contrary enſignes armes field part cannot maintained ſafe ſide old legion led galen followed ancient new vpſtart nouices wherefore determination determine thus wiſh may approbation beſt matter fat avery oyly efficient cauſe congealing colde yet abſolute actuall ſuch colde liuing creature leſſe hotte kind cold curdleth fat philoſopers take colde ſo fat congealed part abſolutelie cold part leſſe hot others ſuch membrane may better exemplified taught precept lead ſoone taken fire exemplification although yet fiery hot caketh together concretion eyther vertue heat cold fiery heate melted actuall cold touch thus caked burne therefore remiſſe heate ſtead colde certaine degree heate ſuffer lead cake fat curdle degree onely fleſhy part whence fat neuer growes membranous part becauſe haue ſame degree heate doe curdle oylie part blood fat veſſell boyling water couered though couer leſſe heate taken cold hot yet vapour water turneth ſteame vppon ſtand drop yea run water ſee stils though head ſo hotte man cannot touch reaſon becauſe couer leſſe heate boyling water heated onely vapour water immediatelie fire leſſe heate therefore couer head ſtead colde boyling water like manner melancholy men hot boyling entrals raiſe vapour come skin leſſe hot entrals gathered thickned melancholy men ſweate much ſweate breathing vapour lower part raiſed hot braine yet leſſe hot lower part turned water fal rheumes gowts ſuch like manner therefore wee ſay fatte curdles colde leſſer heate melt ſo wee ſay brayne cold leſſe hot although hotter haue ſayd ayre bee heate ſummer ſummer ayre hot gleames wee call hot ſo yet colde reſpect fieryheat liue fire yea cold reſpect heate liuing creature heart refrigerated life proportionable fire true rule metaphyſicks logicke meanes contrary extreames anſwere former argument meanes contrary extreames elſe ſhould liberality vertue contrary couetouſnes prodigality extreames vice theſe thing thus firſt determined anſwere argument vrged againſt v firſt deny concretion coagulation done actuall colde ſayd lead yet firie hot congeale whereas fat groweth heart hotteſt part anſwere herein great document wonderfull wonderfull prouidēce nature prouident wiſedom nature hath thus prouided leaſt perpetuall motion hart ſhould gather ſo great heat ſhould waſte conſume cauſe alſo ſaith hippo lyeth water much like vrine might euer freſh flouriſhing chryſippus notable stoicke booke prouidence ſayeth finall cauſe ouercommeth efficient matter naturall thinges ariſtotle againſt democritus finall cauſe firſt chiefeſt work nature ſayth workes nature end firſt chiefe cauſe moueth cauſes ſelfe immoueable know aduerſaries obiect nature indeuoureth nothing againſt owne lawes ſhee ſhould therefore haue made heart temperate let retort owne weapon againſt nature ſhould haue made heart originally temperate might haue beene neede breathing cold ayre abſurd oppoſition againſt wiſedome nature man ſeeth heart neceſſarily bee created hotte becauſe hearth fire whereby naturall heate part preſerued refreſhed thinke fat heart neceſſary let remember groweth ventricle fleſh heart onely vpon membrane veſſels part leſſe hot add fat part heart becauſe keepeth alwayes ſame figure circumſcription melted fire rather torrifieth membrane braine ſay haue fat becauſe vſe yea would haue hindered breathing ſmoaky vapor clammineſſe fat braine braine like cupping glaſſe draweth continually ſucketh vp expiration inferior part comblike ſutures skul gape giue way braine would made drunke aboundant moyſtures beſide fat would haue hindred motion brain moueth perpetually pulſe doth ſhall ſhew due place wherefore braine wanteth finall cauſe fat materiall cauſe alſo wanting becauſe required great aboundance bloud nouriſhment brain generation animall ſpirits behoued therefore ſhould conuerted fat old men thoſe melancholy diſpute next exerciſe finally whereas galen ſayth cold dry body fatte larded fleſh coates membrane anſwere fleſh place vnderſtandeth muſcles couered galen expounded proper coates coates fat groweth body ſuch galen ſpeaketh ther ſuch aboundance bloud ſhould ouerplus effect fat mention conclude nothing true fat concocting medicine fat kall relieueth heat ſtomacke primarily ſelfe euent becauſe thicknes viſciditie clammines hindreth euaporation heate meanes doubled beſides ſtoppeth vp pore piercing cold cannot reach vnto wherefore heateth ſtomacke fat heateth ſtomacke cloathes heat body blacke fleſh parenchyma congealed bloud ful fibre parenchyma eraſistratus called fleſhy affuſion ſoft thin looſe ſpongious might eaſily draw thick iuyces farre ſpongie ſubſtance fitter purpoſe faſt firme giue entertainment wherefore alſo veines diſſeminated ſofter looſer others humour may eaſily though thicke fall vſe ſpleene eraſiſtratus thought none inconſiderately accuſing eraſiſtratus receiued opinion vſe • ſpleene nature haue framed vaine receiued opinion ordayned bee receptacle craſſer foeculent part bloud made ſeparated liuer like bladder gall receptacle yellow choller bloud thus either hand depured might paſſe cleare neate nouriſh body eſpecially principall part thick impure bloud yet mingled much good laudable ſpleene ſpleenicke braunch gateveine inbred faculty draweth vnto ſelfe familiar kin vnto ſubſtance albeit veines liuer could change yet ſpleene reaſon perpetuall motion many large artery worketh owne nouriſhment notwithſtanding remayneth vnprofitable part belcheth ſtomacke ſhort veſſell ſtirre vp appetite aciditie ſharpnes adſtriction corroborate confirme action ſtomacke againſt common receiued opinion bauhine place annexeth long diſcourſe full wit lower part abdomen receptacle excrement ſo woulde commodiouſly haue receiued ſo heauy earthy excrement againe ſeeing humour leaſt quantitie melancholy nature would haue made ſpleene bigger bladder gall ſhee intended ſome office ſpleene beſide receite melancholly moreouer beene end ſhe would haue framed ſpleene large cauitie humour might haue commodiouſly beene entertayned ſhe framed cauitie attracteth laudable bloud sixtly paſſages choller diſperſed ſubſtance liuer among rootes gate hollow veines draw away excrementitions choller alſo ſhould haue beene many propagation tendril ſpleenick braunch diſperſed ſubſtance liuer finde nothing ſo finally liuer foeculent bloud bee purged away excrement ſpleene muſt neceſsity follow excrementitious humour ſhould regurgitate returne trunke firſt allotted author bauhines ſide ariſtotle galen aphrodiſaeus aretaeus veſalius fernelius platerus archangelus vnto therefore third booke de partibus animalium 7 chapter hee calleth baſtard liuer ſame alſo galen giueth aſſent vnto booke de reſpirationis vſu alſo aphrodiſaeus aretaeus veſalius fernelius touch vpon vſe ſpleene alſo platerus archangelus reſolue vpon confidently ſpleene therefore inbred faculty owne draweth vnto himſelfe thicker earthie portion chylus ſomewhat altered hauing receiued certain diſpoſition rudiment bloud meſeraicke veines ſpleenick branch gateveine trunke meſeraick veines chylus get liuer ſo liuer may better draw laudable part chylus otherwiſe ſmall veſſels liuer obſtructed craſſe crude bloud bauhines proiect onely ſanguification would haue beene interrupted alſo iaundiſe dropſies ague scirrous hardneſſes many miſchiefes woulde haue ouertaken v neceſſity ſee euery day hapen ſpleen fayleth duty either weakneſſe obſtructions ceaſeth attract craſſe foeculent part chylus great euidence trueth ſpleenicke branch doeth proceede liuer ariſeth ſayde ſeated neither likely ſo thicke iuyce confected made bloud liuer ſhould get hairie threddy veines ſame yet wee doe deny melancholly iuyce ingendred liuer wee ſay onely ingendered part maſſe bloud receiued ſpleen nouriſhment vſe ſtomacke furthermore opinion ſaith bauhine part chylus ſucked euen ſtomack veines ariuing left ſide bottom ſpleenicke branch ſpleen hath receiued chylus little altered long iourney thoſe ſpleenicke ſurcles branch laboureth worketh great leaſure long proceſſe alchymiſts ſay much preparation innumerable ſmall veſſels fibrous complication diſſeminated ſubſtance like greater part chylus laboured bloud complication veſſelles diſſeminated liuer boyleth thinner eſtabliſh ſettle nimble quick motion vitall ſpirits great cauſe ſome men wit ſo giddy vnconſtant sometimes falleth great confirmed diſeaſes liuer ſanguification ſomewhat ſtrange decayed manner helpe liuer confecting blood partly becauſe maketh blood anſwerable owne nature partly becauſe auerteth draweth aſide vnto ſelfe thicker part aliment ſo fit make pure blood meanes liuer vnburdened hippocrates called 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 wagon nouriſhment whereas aliment ſo ſimple conſiſteth diuers different part muſt know thoſe part cannot changed laudable bloud wherefore firſt concoction firſt bilious cholericke excrement diſpoſed partly bladder gall partly ſent away gut ſhall ſay next chapter ſecond ſerous whaey humor greateſt part whereof bloud ariued rootes gateveine hollow veine becommeth offenſiue burden vnto therefore kidneyes emulgent veines artery draw hollow veine great arterie themſelues bloud thus cleanſed depured manner excrement diſtributed trunkes branch hollow ſpirite fift galen chapter 12 booke method yet notwithſtanding beyond controuerſie conteined artery plainly ſixt vſe part writeth ſpirit conteined veines yet thoſe darke ſayeth cloudy confeſſe naturall faculty bred naturall ſpirit cloudy ſeated euery part becauſe heate naturall ſpirit partes wherein inbredde faculty doth conſiſt vncertaine like fugitiue dull ſtupid ſtandeth neede another influent yet like vnto itſelfe whereby might bee ſtirred vp eſtabliſhed potentiall vertue brought operatiue act arabian imagine blood tranſported guided whole body arabian conceit vnder conduct ſpirit although euery part like loadſtone doe draw vnto itſelfe ſuch iuyce familiar vnto yet diſtance place great neither loadſtone draw yron amber chaffe part nouriſhment ſecond argument wanteth nouriſhment generation preſeruation ſpirit becauſe ayre conuayed vnto liuer anſwere hippocrates ſecond hippocrates body tranſpirable tranſfluxible ſo open ayre may eaſily paſſe repaſſe though ſo aboundantly doth continual motion fanne ventilateth fanneth liuer onely entralles thirdly whereas ſay cauity ciſterne place generation ſuch ſpirit liuer truely bold concluſion let v ſticke third great confidence hauing galen ſides equiualent whole army ſuch inexperienced tyrones neceſſary ſayth ſhould cauity cell liuer ſuch heart becauſe thoſe bowelles onely either receiue others affoorde impart togetherward plentifull aboundant ſourſe matter ſtood neede ample cauity wherein ſhould either treaſured ſtored receiued wrought framed bee conuayed vitall ſpirit fine thinne therefore quickly exhauſted ſo behoued ſhould ſodainely bee regenerated might neither want plenty neceſſity aboundance ſodain expence therefore neceſſary ſhould haue large cauitie cauldron wherein ſhould boyled prepared vſe wee ſee nature affluence thereof therefore bed web veines ſufficient generation fourthly whereas ſay thinne coates veines weake guide ſafeconduct naturall ſpirit anſwere word thicke groſſe ſubſtance fourth dull irradiation heart ſhal prooue hereafter finally aske think theſe ſpirits ſhould nouriſhed anſwere tranſpiration preſerueth refreſheth maintaineth euery veine hath laſt artery accompanying continually choyces may naturall election vnto place thinke fewe men reaſon auouch likely either drawne driuen galen ſo reaſon alſo although fallopius ſubtle occulate anatomiſt contendeth galen onely driuen liuer paſſages right left ventricle lunge columbus thought therefore spleene moreouer perſwaded ſaith heereunto ſtructure spleene ſelfe symptomes accident follow thoſe ſplenetick ſtructure hippocrates firſt booke de morbis mulerum ſaith spleene rare ſpongy another tongue beſide innumerable foulds artery therein hippocrates theſe foulds ordained new elaboration therefore braine wonderfull admirable web formed teſticles mazy veſſels liuer million veines wherefore followeth nature hath ordained ſpleene preparing attenuating vitall bloode add heereto symptomes ſpleniticke perſons liuid leaden colour truely proue greateſt part matter vrine ſupplyed drinke liquid meates conclude neceſſarily thoſe anſwere onely alone matter infant auoydeth water mother wombe veſſell called vrachos yet drinketh euacuations bladder purulent perirrhaea ſuch accompanied strangury symptomes thereof remaineth vpon record cōcerning matter ſolemn edict hippocrates ſecond ſection firſt hippocrates galen booke epidemi • n ſaith many doe auoid vrines bilious watery purulent fretting ſtrangurious yſſuing drop becauſe galen interpreteth whole body put downe vrines great abundance variety euil humor expurgation ſhall haue occaſion ſpeake another place neither humor onely alſo ſuch body colliquated melted matter vrine ſuch fat fleſhy hence come thoſe fat oyle water conſuming ague melteth body called ſignes colliquation whereof hippocrates hippocrates ſpeaketh prognoſtiques manner vrine ill oylie fat made oylineſſe doth vnderſtand either colour conſiſtence oyly vrine oyle melted colliquated greace ſwimming ſurface vvater concerning threefold matter vrine ludouicus duretus great learned man ludouicus duretus france hath written large elegant learned commentary coacas praenotiones hippocrates theſe thing therefore ſo matter vrine ſo manifold conclude concluſion vrine drawne kidneyes onely naturally diſpoſed wit whey foure humor contained veines notwithſtanding kidneyes therewithall nouriſhed traction nouriſhment loadſtone draweth iron amber chaffe yet nouriſhed vrine hath matter crude humor freely aboundantly poured forth criticall day thinke onely driuen drawne vrine flow accord moſt patent ample veſſels kidnies becauſe thoſe place moſt accuſtomed euacuation take ſum ſubſtance controuerſie qvest xix reaſons diuers symptomes follow ſuch afflicted stone required anatomy belongeth neyther place time diſpute cauſes generation ſtone rather ſticke thoſe thing concerne anatomy becauſe nephritical patient ſuch troubled kidneyes eſpecially stone haue diuers accident wherof reaſon giuen onely anatomy haue thought amiſſe briefely lay open ſeuerall cauſes ſatisfaction ſuch ſo well exerciſed art notwithſtanding may deſire ſatisfaction point nephritical paine doth oftentimes immitate collicke ſo ſimilitude onely ignorant ſuch right skilfull often deceiued notwithſtanding diſtinguiſhed particular symptomes thoſe thing auoided thoſe applyed moſt greeuous symptom reſt paine collicke wandering fixed stone collick paine aſcendeth like collick gut aſcendeth bottome belly ſtomacke ſo runneth vnder bottome thereof stone deſcendeth becauſe continuity vreters eſpecially stone begin mooue collicke paine poſſeſſeth paine wandering fixed lower belly nephritick may couered one hand collick greeueth region hypogaſtrium nauell stone lyeth forer loines backward haue obſerued arabian collicke paine leſſe stomacke obſeruation arabian empty exaſperated againe ſtomacke filled collicke encreaſeth muſt thus vnderſtood collick paine euer abateth ſtomacke gut empty nephritick alwaies becauſe ſtone lye goading ſame place yet ſometimes meate nephritick paine abated becauſe ſtone fixed kidneyes waight preſſeth downward thence paine proceedeth ſuch men haue eaten gut ſupport ſuſpend kidnies ſwell ſo paine mittigated alſo ſome nephriticall paine exaſperated vpon eating meate kidneyes inflamed diſtention ſtomacke gut encreaſe againe paine kidneyes beginnes dully collicke alwayes cutting ſharpe paine obiection hippocrates obiected hippocrates booke de internis affectibus affirmeth pain kidneyes ſharpe may anſwere galen double kinde dulneſſe firſt occaſioned tartnes expulſion offendeth weight taketh vp time betwixt generation expulſion thus paine 2 anſwere stone dull whilſt reſteth kidney acute mooueth toward vreter alſo nephriticall symptomes thigh ſame ſide wherein ſtone lie benummed aſleepe ſo collick paine wherein vomiting loathing meate diſtaſtfull belchinges frequent greeuous ſo much ſymptomes secondly theſe paine diſtinguiſhed thoſe thinges auoyded 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 fratrare grow together like twinnes wherefore milke may ſometimes bredde ſuch woman eſpecially whoſe courſes ſtopt hippocrates writeth theſe diſagreeing place reconciliatiō hip two kind milke according hip hippocrates bee hard reconcile hippocrates himſelfe double generation milke according hippocrates double nature thereof one kinde milke true laudable another true perfectly boyled former made great alteration true concoction breaſtes priuate officiall latter ariſeth remainder proper nouriſhment breaſts firſt perfectly white ſweete moderately thicke fitte ſuckle infant white indeed becauſe beareth colour forme part whence floweth hath neither true nature nouriſhing chymus humour ſweetnes power vigour nouriſhment therefore deſerueth name milke quality ſpecificiall forme onely colour thinne wateriſh altogether vnprofitable nouriſh infant former begotten expreſſion refluence blood wombe dugges alſo traction latter onely traction proper aliment former cannot generated true conception becauſe ſhould vſe latter may bee ingendered growne ripe maydens well blooded men whoſe body veſſels abound laudable iuyces double kinde generation milke gather hippocrates bookes de natura pueri de glandulis nature ſayth hee woman breaſtes rare ſpongy aliment draw vnto themſelues turne vnto milke hippocrates firſt kinde generation deſcribeth ſame place milke nutrition therewith infant womb nouriſhed onely birth milke generated ſeauenth month til vſe doth flow womb breſts preſently ſoone conception queſtion hippocrates solution well third fourth month hippocrates booke quoted anſwereth queſtion thus infant third fourth month becomming great dooth straine preſſe veſsels ful bloode compreſsion expreſsion made vnto vpper part reaſon indeede true verie ſubtle obſcure wherefore wil paine darke ſentence hippocrates explained ſelues little make manifeſt firſt month nature expence blood great firſt becauſe parenchymata ſubſtance bowel fleſhy part generated afterwardes nouriſhment growth ſo remaineth little ouer plus mother bloode infant beginnes mooue becauſe alreadie perfect conformation partes nature thereafter onely entendeth nouriſhment nouriſhment requireth ſmall quantity blood returneth wombe rather dugges part aliment becauſe ſmall ſlender exhauſtion expence part therefore veynes wombe muſt needes ouerplus bloode theſe veines preſſed motion weyght infant growne great doe driue blood vnto vpper part rather dugges well becauſe commodiouſneſſe fitneſſe way becauſe ſocietie ſimpathie betwixt wombe breaſts add heereto third cauſe alſo finall wonderfull prouidence nature whereby blood accuſtomed little little tranſported vnto place ſhall bee prouidence nature turned vnto milke ſo remaine plentifull fountaine nouriſhment infant borne world reaſon woman ſo much troubled bleeding noſe woman bleed noſe troubled haemorhoids haemorrhoides becauſe bloode affecteth way vnto wombe ſatisfy ende intent nature generation away whether child would neuer ſtriue come foorth hauing alwayes nouriſhment enough hande content hippocrates hippocrates true cauſe trauel ſaith onely cauſe ſtrifte infant byrth vvant nouriſhment behooued therefore thirde fourth moneths nature ſhould degree transferre bloode vnto dugges accuſtome ſelfe leade thether nouriſhment infant borne alſo defraud infant nowe becomd better growne within vvombe within wombe nouriſhed verie pure bloode vvithout wombe ſweete milke dinus anſwereth bloode dinus anſwer▪ hotter milke ſhould paſſe three concoction child bodie would length become vnmeete nouriſhment becauſe much heate would contract bitterneſſe milke cold temper eaſily mittigated groweth rather ſweete bitter threefold concoction rather inhumane another anſwere beaſtly thing child bloodſuckers ſhall ſay therefore infant byrth nouriſhed bloode leaſt ſucking hee ſhould open mouth mother veines ſo blood treaſure nature ſhould flowe away whereas ſome affirme wee born neceſſary aliment obiection ſhould paſſe three concoction poſsible ſtomacke ſhould chylefie blood therefore infant nouriſhed bloode milke ſay reaſon falſe full error whatſoeuer taken vnto ſtomacke may aſsimulated may alſo turned creamy ſubſtance many drinke anſwer blood swine goat noyſome excrement whereof auoyded guttes ſeidge excrement gut onely excrement chylification thing may concerne anie naturall part belong vnto nutrition becauſe wee imagine eaſilie knowne hard yet generally coacluſion theſe controuerſies agreed vpon willingly paſſe ouer iudging ſufficient haue thus long detained reader theſe labyrinthes controuerſies notwithſtanding may thought neceſſary ſo preſume wil irkeſome man whoſe stomacke ſtandeth theſe delicacy nature vnprofitable thoſe whoſe proper element belong high time returne anatomical hiſtory natural part belonging generation end controuerſies third booke fovrth booke naturall part belonging generation well men vvomen praeface ariued place tract anatomicall perigrination entred deliberation ſelfe whether beſt ſilently paſſe inſiſt vppon done former one ſide conceiued labour would lame argument perſwading v proſecute hiſtory theſe part wanted teſticles hang body themſelues another vſe propendence hanging length reuolutions ſpermaticke veſſels might haue ſcope becauſe change blood ſeede needed manifold diuerſe alteration diſpoſitions behooued veſſels conueyed vnto teſticles ſhould bee great length length paſſage blood might vnder go alteration ſo made fitter receiue forme ſeede ſo great length veſſels capacity belly could fitly receiue therefore teſticles placed without body becauſe neither profitable handſome ſhould hang bare cod receiuing cloathing ſcrotum cod made purſe bagge wherby alſo borne vp whereas owne waight otherwiſe would haue extended drawne length manifould foulds alſo thought ſome muſcles neare hand doe adde ſome helpe purpoſe nature wee ſhall heare hereafter teſticles men larger hotter nature woman ſo much heat thruſteth teſticles body reaſon ſcituation becauſe temperament whole body woman colder men hotter wherefore heat abounding men thruſts foorth body whereas woman remaine within becauſe dull ſluggiſh heate ſufficient thruſt trueth appeareth manifold ſtories ſuch woman whoſe actiue operatiue heate hath thruſt teſticles woman made men ſhall relate hereafter large contouerſies coates teſticles two ſorts common proper common two wee call common onely becauſe common part coat teſticles body alſo becauſe inueſt theſe two teſticles together proper coat alſo two thus determine albeit know great difference author concerning number theſe coates galen nameth three booke de diſſectione vteri 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 veſalius reckons foure falopius ſomtimes three ſomtimes diuers author mankinde ſtructure member ſuch fitteſt vſe neceſsity nature ſtructure bone bony dogge woolfe fox ſo would pleaſure great troble ſexe beſides alwayes rigid ſtiffe woulde haue beene vncomely haue hindered many action poſtures poſitions body griſtly cartilaginous could neither haue beene diſtended griſtle cartilage hath cauitie neither could haue beene ſoft pliable nature veine could ſo ſoone haue beene filled veine emptyed againe alſo ſimple coate veine would haue endured ſtrong ſtreatching nature arterie although haue thicke hard coate becauſe artery continuall pulſation vpon man cannot lay law pleaſeth neruous becauſe nerues haue manifeſt cauitie neither naturally nerue dilated beſide ſoftnes would haue hindered tenſion erection ligament although would haue fit tenſion erection becauſe ligament ſhould haue cauity beſide without ſence would haue capable pleaſure tendon becauſe haue cauity beſide ſofter ligament tendon ſo ſo fit erection much leſſe could well made fleſh altogether allowed whole body diſtendeth yea enrageth hippocrates ſaith ſeede nature fiery aery aery part diſtendeth whole frame nature fiery ſetteth worke gog ſay tranſporting body onely minde compariſon alſo reaſon rage leaſt part mortall poyſon moment changeth whole body ſo ſeede whoſe quality ſo actiue operatiue darteth forth irradiation beames whole body thence ſee gelt creature ſo ſtirring others whoſe many motion ſtirre vp ſo encreaſe heate may obiected galen another placce attributeth onely liuer heart power change whole body teſticles thus hee ſayeth thoſe galen redeemed ſome thinke woman haue ſo ſmal inſenſible ſaith begge queſtion againe think abſurd ſay neck forme ſtructure part wombe inuerted like member man necke womb hath one cauity long large like ſneath receiue virile member member yard man conſiſteth two hollow nerues common paſſage ſeede vrine foure muſcles neyther cauity man yard ſo large ample necke wombe add necke bladder woman doth equall length necke womb men equalleth whole length member yard howſoeuer therefore necke wombe ſhall inuerted yet neuer make virile member three hollow body cannot made one yard conſiſteth three hollow body generation neither doth hippocrates ſay ſo plainly contrary addeth tried meanes could bring downe courſes ſhe periſhed wherefore hir part generation remained thoſe woman although bodye grew manniſh hairie qvest ix motion wombe another queſtion whether wombe moue locally mathematically womb ſaide mooue phyſically onely concerning wil reſolue thus threefold motion wombe one altogether naturall another altogether symptomicall convulſiue third mixt partly naturall partly symptomical threefolde motion naturall motion meerely faculty ſoule symptomatical meerly vnhealthfull cauſe third together naturall motion wombe draweth ſeed neck bottom runneth downward meete inſomuch ſometimes hath beene ſeene euen natural motion wombe fall mooueth alſo naturally conception contracted imbraceth ſeede ſtrictly euery ſide alſo excludeth infant afterbirth thing contayned beſide nature accompliſhment motion hath right fibre many tranſuerſe ouerthwart motion come neceſsity nature ſymptomaticall motion onely cauſe morbous diſeaſefull ſymptomatical motion wombe ſuffocati er ſtrangulation matrixe convulſiue motion manifeſt ſuffocation matrixe wombe moued vpward becauſe drawne convulſiuely come either repletion exhauſtion emptines ligament either drought exſiccated ſteeped ouermuch moyſture ſometimes commeth poyſonous breath ſuppreſsion courſes retention corruption woman ſeede falne veſſels convulſiue motion midriffe preſſed borne vp chiefe inſtrument ſuch woman breath free reſpiration breathing braine alſo drawn conſent chiefe ſeate tribunall animall faculty faculty efficient cauſe reſpiration hence ſuch ſuffocations ſtrangulations interception cauſes reſpiration ſuffocation taken away reſpiration inſtrumentall cauſe midriffe intercepted efficient cauſe animal faculty alſo becauſe braine drawn conſent finall cauſe alſo taken away heat heart time ſmall requireth therefore ventilation tranſpiration pore habit body muſt marke cal motion convulſion onely convulſiue motion convulſion properly vnbidden motion thoſe part vſe moue part ſuffer convulſions commandement wombe mooued willes owne wherefore convulſions belong wombe muſcles onely inſtruments voluntary motion abuſiuely may call convulſion hippocrates calleth hiccocke convulſion third motion wombe wee ſayed mixt proceeding morbous 3 mixt motion wombe vnhealthy cauſe partly faculty great exiccation runneth vpward toward liuer fountaine ſweete moyſture dried partes doe thirſt moyſture naturall appetite motion indeede truely mixt partly phyſicall naturall dry wombe drawing toward ſeate moyſture drawing conceyueth veſſelles theſe part communicate almoſt anatomiſtes agree branch aſcending epigaſtrick veine meete one branch deſcending mammarie veine theſe branch many anaſtomoſes inoculation doe deny another likely crurall veine likewiſe veine call mammaria breſt veine runneth inner mamarie veine part breſtbone nouriſh triangular muſcle neither doth ſend branch breſts vnleſſe ſmall threddy ſuppoſe therfore ſaith blood milke humour doe flowe backe hypogaſtricke ſpermaticall veynes proper veines wombe vnto trunke hollow veine vein called axillaris ſhoulder vein ariſe two notable cheſt hypogaſtrick ſper maticall veines called thoracicae water muſcles cheſt glandules kernel breſt ſide conceiue milk returneth thoracicall veines axillarie vnto trunke hollow veine paſſeth ſomtimes membrane called hymen markes virginitie hath old queſtion ſo continueth day whether certaine markes note virginity woman hymen thought ſome almoſt phyſitians thinke certain membrane ſometimes middeſt necke wombe ſometimes immediately paſſage water placed ouerthwart call hymen membrane ſay perforated middeſt giue way courſes broken torne firſt accompanying men therefore call lock virginity clauſtrum virginitatis lock virginity opinion bring teſtimonies holy ſcriptures cuſtome among iewes bride ſhould cuſtome among iewes accompany bridegroomes vpon ſheete wherein bloud ſhould bee kept giuen bride parent witneſſe daughter true virginity falopius yeeldeth opinion columbus writeth hath ſeene laurentius ſayeth laurentius opinion hath cut vp mayden child borne time three moneths 3 4 6 7 yeares old yet hee could neuer finde though ſearched curiouſly probe ſayth might haue beene felt reſiſt probe beene ſuch thing therfore thinketh meere fable yet notwithſtanding thus far giueth credite columbus falopius hee thinketh ſometimes ſuch membrane found ſtretched ouerthwart middle end neck wombe hee thinketh naturall organicall diſeaſe inſtrument faulty conformation oftentimes end extremity ſpoken concerning partes generation men woman controuerſies thereto longing honi ſoit que mal penſe end controuerſies fourth booke fift booke wherein hiſtorie infant acurately deſcribed alſo principle hiſtory part generation conſidering contained many thing profitable pleaſant alſo thought good gentle reader make thee partaker thereof rather heere perſwaded ſelfe becauſe firſt ſight conceiued ſelfe excrement seede part body aliment colliquation therefore excrement part becauſe part whilſt remaineth v nothing made neither hath body vſe eſpecially matter add heereto part ſo often loſt creature ſhould become maimed aliment ſhould auoyded much leſſe colliquation aliment colliquation colliquation thing beſide nature ſeede truly naturall yea quinteſſence nature man thoſe thing fat moſt ſubiect colliquation melting know fat men haue leaſt quantity ſeede moreouer colliquation may bee made moiſture part body ſeede hath owne determinate limited ſeate wherein contained colliquation alwayes diſsimilar ſubſtance firſt called excrement onely reaſon abounding quantitie thereof ſecond noxious hurtfull euen qualitie alſo chylus made ſtomacke acceptable euen ſtomacke pained concocting thereof principle ſpirit immediate proportionable inſtrument nature wherby noble architect ſoule extendeth membrane produceth lengtheneth paſſages kinde puffing ſufflation perforateth therefore double matter ſeede blood ſpirits hence among philoſophers ſeede eſteemed haue double nature one aery ſpumous frothy double nature ſeed another wateriſh diffluent ſeed aery neuer congealed frozen wateriſh ſooner owne veſſels melteth ſpirits vaniſhed vnite part whereas ſome affirme ſeed onely wateriſh becauſe colour like water alſo conſiſtence hath bin little time veſſels ſeede water differ ariſtotle againſt oppoſe aristotle diſputeth point ſecond chapter ſecond booke de generatione animalium ſaith nature water ſeede different water heate becommeth thicke ſeede doth wateriſn thing colde congealed ſeede made fluid 51 problem firſt section ſaith ſeede like flegme water nature onely colour proceede double matter mingled theſe labyrinth vein openeth double matter mingled artery artery veine wonderfull inoculation ſo two becommeth one veſſel embleme holy mixtion ſeedes matrimony two veſſels veine artery made one veſſell ſo double matter blood embleme matrimony ſpirits made one ſeede two ſeeds male female one infant two parent husband wife one body returne blood ſpirits thus mingled attaine preparing veſſels rudiment ſeede ſo much inbred power faculty veſſels themſelues irradiation beaming influence haue teſticles finally epididymis mixture becommeth ſeede teſticles ſeed boyled proper ingenit vertue whoſe ſubſtance rare ſpongy friable theſe deriued eiaculatory veſſels ouer plus peculiar excrement teſticles whence manifeſt fruitfull prolificall ſeede yſſueth onely teſticles whole body ſhal prooue next exerciſe qvest iiii whether ſeede fall part body thinkes ſee faire large fielde wherein may expatiate diſport ſelfe little reſtraining diſcourſe within thoſe narrow cancel wherein haue formerly confined common receyued olde receiued opinion opinion old time ſeede flow part body part ſicke diſeaſed diſeaſed part hence lame men beget lame child bald men bald child spleniticke men child afflicted spleene opinion confirmed foure reaſons firſt becauſe acte generation confirmd foure reaſons copulation whole bodie delighted ſtupified extaſie pleaſure wil ſuffereth pleaſant convulſion whence coition called parua epilepſia light fit falling ſickneſſe ſaide euen ſecond reaſon becauſe childe beareth carracter father imperfection balde men balde child lame men lame child ſo likewiſe cenſe hereditary diſeaſes thirdly becauſe thoſe immoderate vſe venus doe waſte conſume part hee wanteth ioynt begetteth childe ioynts immoderate coition whole body reſolued conſumed happeneth becauſe remaynders aliment spirit ſuch men exhauſted whereof partes defrauded muſt neceſſity waſte conſume therefore auicen ſayeth great expence seede waſteth bodye fortie time ſo much expence loſſe bloud loſſe bee proportionable finally obtrude concerning likeneſſe childeren parent belongeth et locis firſt ſuch men called 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 scithians tymes paſt among inhabitant europe certayne men called macrocephali great eſteeme whoſe heades long ſuch accounted macrocephali noble generous ſpirites therefore nurſes wont preſſe tender head infant lengthen ſwathes till length thoſe cuſtom conſtraint long head begat child long head naturally conformation without conſtraint rude ſcarcely knowne man therefore many ſayings concerning anatomy wee cannot age rude anatomicall diſſections either vnderſtand giue conſent vnto sure manifeſt conſpicuous paſſages yet found brayn may cauſe barrennes quoted hee ſayeth amongest scythian richeſt moſt noble weere moſt others thus affected poorer ſorte leaſt noble ſpirites becauſe vſed ride much incurred theſe miſchiefes whereas bookes de semine 14 book de vſu partium elegantly diſcuſſeth whole queſtion wherefore hath large many word exemplified wee place contract draw briefe ſumme ſhall therefore three head diſputation firſt propound reaſons peripatetiks secondly three heades controuerſie giue view opinion phyſitians laſtly wee anſwere obiections brought againſt truth aristotle bookes de generatione animalium contendeth woman neither looſe argumēts peripatetiks woman haue ſeede ſeede acte generation neither yet indeede haue ſeede theſe reaſons firſt becauſe abſurd thinke woman ſhould double ſecretion blood ſeede secondly becauſe woman voice haire habit body moſt like vnto boyes boyes breede ſeed thirdlie becauſe woman ſometimes conceiue without pleaſure yea againſt wils auerrhoes telleth story woman bath together ſome men receyued ſeed fell floted water thereupon conceiued fourthly becauſe woman vnperfect male hath actiue power onely paſſiue generation finally becauſe woman ſhould looſe ſeed might engender without helpe male becauſe haue themſelues principle generation wit menſtruall blood contrary phyſitians bring ſtronger argument prooue woman yeeld opinion phyſitians ſeede firſt men efficient materiall cauſes generation yet cannot ſhe generate ſelfe without helpe man ſpeake lawfull generation becauſe ſeede weake cold ſee henns wil lay egges without cocke cal addle egges becauſe neuer proue chickins yea neither cockes egges ſometimes lay proue thing wherfore concourſe confluence ſeedes ſexes abſolute neceſsity generation valeſius anſwereth obiection thus woman cold abortments ſometimes hath bin obſerued geniture diſprooued yſſuing woman ſeuenth day conception hath bin dearticulated ſo hath appeared rudiment three principall part threds al ſpermaticall part thing firſt generation alwayes laſt diſſolution generation thing mixed matter goeth forme yet abolition forme corruption thing mixed reaſon alſo hart doth firſt liue snake serpent tayle ſhould liueth firſt becauſe part ſtarke dead immouable yet tayle liueth moueth think indeed heart laſt depriued life becauſe infant perfected abſolued vitall heate floweth onely heart moſt plentifull fountaine firſt liueth vtterly deny becauſe liue either noriſhed animated heart neither firſt nouriſhed firſt animated nouriſhment blood liue blood veines veines liuer vmbilicall veine firſt nurſe embryo powreth blood parenchyma liuer heart neither heart firſt animated becauſe ſeed breaketh act beginneth conformation wholly actually animated therfore part thereof doe actually liue onely participation heate moyſture wee bid therefore adue ariſtotle chyſippus stoyckes whoſoeuer elſe doe thinke heart firſt liuer firſt maker bloud galen ſeemeth differ himſelfe order conformation part galen diuers doe deſire company male becauſe ſhould bee matter new ſeede conſumed nouriſhment young therefore goaded wonted luſt woman becauſe ſhe hath aboundance moyſture hath alſo veſſels full ſeede whence come motion ſenſe obſcoene part reaſon cannot approue although infant conſume diſproued almoſt reliques ſurpluſage blood yet doth defraude part mother body conuenient nouriſhment neither taketh teſticles conformation wombe creature great yong wombe nearer outward part therefore danger violated male whoſe genitals great length moſt part harder ſubſtance woman womb ſcituated inward beyond man reach therefore ſhe beareth eaſilier beaſts vſe venus second onely giuen preſeruation kinde therefore conceiue finall cauſe ſatisfied deſire coition alſo appeaſed man vſeth theſe pleaſures onely propagate antients dreamt wonderfull prouidence nature womb certaine time open ſelfe auoyde thoſe thing might otherwiſe offend time woman child ſhould accompany man wombe might entertaine ſeed conſuted ſo breede superfoetation take theſe idle addle imagination whole courſe thoſe nine month wombe ſhould certaine time open ſelf expell ſuperuacuous lochia thoſe purgation iſſue trauel reteined time womb womb ſame time auoideth wherewith offended receiue alſo ſeede whereby pleaſed conceiue ſame rather ſeed would ſo extinguiſhed among late writer ſome thinke wombe neuer ſo exquiſitly ſhut may admit ſeede opinion eſtabliſh theſe reaſons another opinion new writer reaſon 1 woman child often auoide courſes pallid flegmatick black queſtion lay lurking cauity vvombe therefore orifice thereof ſo perfectly ſhut againe woman childe coition looſeth ſeede ſhe perceyueth yſſue lap way could yſſue vnleſſe came thorough necke cauity wombe becauſe woman eiaculateth ſeede ſides bottome wombe orifice therefore wombe alwayes open ſo hapneth ſuperfoetation eaſily theſe argument think haue cauſe diſproued whereas want skill anatomy caſt miſt ouer hippocrates sunſhine may anſwer firſt argument manifeſt maner reaſoning ignorant firſt reaſon ſatisfied two veines diſperſe branch wombe ſome carried inward cauity thereof infant nouriſhed others run outward part wombe euen vnto necke lap ſelfe theſe time ingrauidation go childe bloode yſſueth ſuperfluities body purged without interruption although inward orifice wombe neuer ſo cloſely ſhut latter reaſon would vrge ſecond reaſon anſwered finde two paſſages whereby woman ſeede auoyded firſt paſſage determineth horne ſides wombe ſeede eiaculated boſome wombe woman childe ſhorter opener way paſſage vnknown ancient many alſo later arteriall bloud infant draweth vmbilicall artery prepared life whole embryo conſeruation naturall heate doth redde thick parenchyma lung yet moued ſtand need ſo great quantity thinne arteriall bloud one veine call nurſe embryo ſufficeth arterial blood ſpent nouriſhment lung nouriſhment whole infant ſhould one ſmall artery haue ſufficient nouriſhing cheriſhing lung little part infant nature made two vmbilicall artery thoſe notable one branched chorion infinite ſurcles moreouer bloud infant draweth vmbilicall artery conſumed nouriſhing lung theſe abſurdities would follow firſt lung nouriſhed bloud like vnto ſubſtance pure bloud vmbilicall artery doe returne bloud iliacke branch trunk aorta great arterie wherefore arteriall bloud mother ſhall bee mingled arteriall bloud infant hee ſayth generated left ventricle heart thence diffuſed pipe great artery ſo come paſſe one ſhall offend another ſame veſſel ſhall one ſame time perpetually two contrary motion one bloud aſcending iliacke braunches lung another arteriall bloud deſcending lefte ventricle heart ſame iliacke branch thing albeit confeſſe ſomtimes hapneth critical euacuations notable indeuours nature ſo ſhould perpetuall cannot perſwaded let v wipe away myſt eye let v beleeue two vmbilicall artery made vſe lung alone alſo whole body let v come vnto vſe inoculation petreus conceit hollow veine perforated venall artery attaine ſome dayes ſeauenth yet plainly book de alimento hath deſcribed septimeſtres octimeſters nonimeſtres decimeſtres partus length breaketh theſe word theſe month begotten rather breede fewer haue ſeene ſhooting stagges horne euery yeare fall grow againe seuerinus pinaeus phyſiologicall anatomicall work ſame opinion alſo ſtrengtheneth ſome reaſons ſeuenth moneth ſayth wombe pinaeus opiniō firſt reaſon infant doth alwayes aſcend ſeauenth moneth hee deſcendeth prepareth himſelfe toward enlargement time priuities woman childe moyſtned mucous ſlime part dilated relaxed humour alſo degree griſtles ſharebones inebriated birth might bee laxe furthermore almoſt griſtles body progreſſe ſecond time doe dry bony ſubſtance may ſeene chinne cartilage tyeth together ſharebones remayneth griſtlely end life neither euer becommeth bony becauſe birth diſtended enlarged moreouer third well conſider virgin 16 18 yeares old againe take notice haue conceiued thou ſhalt perceiue hanches diſtended hypogastrium enlarged buttockes become broader eſpecially neere time theyr deliuerance therefore followeth thoſe partes dilated moreouer thoſe fourth haue liued long virgin haue harder trauels yonger wench becauſe griſtles thoſe place dried leſſe relaxed finally ſuch neuer haue conceiued haue thinner griſtles ſuch haue ofteneſt conceiued haue moſt thicke broadeſt hanches wherefore birth fift ſharebones parted aſſunder one another hanchbones o hiſtory sacrum holybone confirmation opinion telleth story woman new deliuered ſhortly hanged whoſe ſharebones ſo diſtracted one coxa
