odour acte exhalation exhalation cannot raiſed heate moyſture followeth therefore heate moiſture neceſſarie production odor neceſſary ſay perſe odour per accidens becauſe cannot actually exiſt without exhalation vrge odour ſelfe nothing knowledge obiection thereof knowledge non en without againe ſubſtance perſe ſelfe cannot knowne therefore ſay take away euen vniuerſall nature science whatſoeuer either ſubſtance solution accident third thing none indeede grant odour conſidered ſelfe ſeparatedly knowledge ſo conſidered nothing neither knowledg accident without ſubſtance doth fall vnder senſe ioyned exhalation mooueth senſe alſo falleth vnder science knowledge like manner accident ſeparated ſubſtances ſubſtances ſeparated accident doe fall vnder science mutually knowne demonſtrated qvest l concluding fiſhes smell peripatetian ſaith placentinus may obiect manner odour haue actuall exiſtence onely exhalation ſo without cannot mooue ſenſe ſhall wee ſay fiſhes liue obiection peripatetiks water exhalation found ariſtotle beginning fift chapter booke de senſu ſenſili ſaith fumid exhalation made water reaſon becauſe ſoone ayre engendred water riſeth vp bubble vve may anſwere fiſhes liue pure neate element water water compounded foure water conſiſteth foure element element therefore compounded ſome fire fire alwayes woorketh worke conſumeth moyſture ſuch conſumption abſolued exhalation eleuation vapor seeing therefore water may found ſuch euaporation may haply imagined fiſhes apprehend odour ſaith author may thredde hard twiſted finely ſpun becauſe firſt wee muſt acknowledge fiſhes ſmell wonderfull dull becauſe predominance moyſture colde vvater againe doubt ridiculous ioyne fire water two contrary ſame ſubiect againſt law contrariety ſurely blame ſhould worthily deſerue ſhould make fire water equall degree wee giue preheminence vnto water ſay fire alſo element put quality vnder girdle doe ſay fire remitted loſt water quality fire extinguiſhed quenched water remitted abated fire worketh perpetually whereſoeuer raiſeth vapour although neuer ſo ſmall action neceſſarily followeth eſſentiall forme fire ſo ſeparate fire take away whole ſubſtance philoſophers opinion foure element onely potentiallie compound bodyes therefore haue onely potentiall vertues ſo fire obiection onely potentially water cannot actually worke vpon wee anſwere vvater actually compounded foure element thoſe element muſt neceſſarilie bee actually vvhich potentially cannot make actuall beeing exiſtence ſay water mixed fire doth fire warme surely doth warme although bee able remooue coldneſſe water solution ſhould appeare warme vnto touchf water pure ſincere certain would bee much cold water may bee proued well water ſomewhat deepe within earth hotter winter summer reaſon becauſe winter wellwater warm winter ſurface earth condenſed cloſed vp ſo internall elementary heate preſerued within earth sommer face earth looſned relaxed iſſueth ayre hence alſo water heated ouer fire would ſooner freeze newly taken riuer becauſe boyling ouer fire inbred heat water vaniſheth becauſe part relaxed diſunited freſh ſpring water natiue heat remaineth preſerueth freezing theſe thing could thus except fire actually water alſo actually heate notwithſtanding phyloſophers may ſome ſort held excuſed becauſe phyloſophets excuſed pure element diſtinguiſhed ſeuerally one another compoūd body potētially actually pure element ſay becauſe fire naturally mixed water water ſome litle odour litle odor fiſhes perceiue canot man cannot ſmell water fiſhes therefore could would follow senſe smelling perfect fiſhes men vtterly falſe neither anſwer ſay water hath odor therein odorated reſpect siccity becauſe siccity potential vnleſſe humidity actually predominant conſumed ſhall neuer able mooue senſe actuall odour requireth actuall siccity actuaally predominant ſome man may obiect fire water rayſeth vp exhalation aud ſo odour grant indeede water exhalation may generated none ſuch ariſtotle difference betwixt moyſt dry exhalation vnderſtandeth odoriferous becauſe thoſe exhalation meerely vaparous wherein siccity yet actually ouercome humiditie humide exhalation ſubiects actuall odour neuer found water alſo ariſtotle confeſſeth notwithſtanding ſame ariſtotle prooueth fiſhes doe ſmell becauſe make choyce meat ſhould ſay chooſe meate smels returne wherefrom wee digreſſed length determine controuerſie wee ſay fiſhes may ſo far foorth smell water wherein liue doth communicate ayre fire ſeeing nothing either bee generated nouriſhed ſimple element muſt needes follow fiſhes ingendered fiſhes cannot ſmell pure water nouriſhed water water partaketh vigour ſubſtance reſt element alſo manifeſted reciprocall tranſmutation change one element another man deny rarified water turneth ayre ayre rarified fire could poſſibly bee water pure vnmixed cannot imagined ſhould receiue put diuers yea contrary nature wherewith hath affinity familiaritie man ſhall perſiſt ſay sea habitation fiſhes pure ſincere element water free commixtion element ſay ſaith placentinus fiſhes cannot smell reaſons firſt becauſe senſe mooued obiects water adulterated mixture heterogeny body cannot produce obiect ſmelling odour dry moyſt freer siccity pure ſimple water againe odoriferous thing plentifull effuſion moyſture doe looſe odour pure ſincere water haue odour therein therefore fiſhes doe ſmell ariſtotle claſſicke authours doe teſtifie muſt needes bee reguard siccity commeth permixtion ayre fre man ſhall obiect water hath ſmell becauſe man cannot perceiue odour thereof though hee ſnuffe noſe hauing notwithſtanding greater perfection senſe fiſhes haue anſwer fiſhes thoſe creature fiſhes ſmell without reſſpiration liue water doe ſmell without reſpiration breathing without thoſe many helpes organ men moreouer water fiſhes familiar element little odour mixed therewith may mooue ſtirre vp ſenſes whereas men muſt bee hot ſteame rayſed odoriferous muſt alſo reſpiration noſe conuay ſame ſteame ſpongie bone vnto mammillary proceſſes senſe mooued whereas aristotle abſolutely concludeth fiſhes doe ſmell becauſe make choyce meate conſequence cannot ſo well approue choyce election meat may proceede another cauſe wee buy victual may ta • ſte weemake choyce eye beleeuing beſt coloured alſo beſt taſted ſhould therefore think fiſhes may make choyce meat ſight againe creature inſtinct nature doe deſire ſeeke aliment proportionable vnto teacheth infant wombe drawe vnto mother blood rather reſt humor ſmell blood nothing fiſhes chooſe meat ſight inſtinct infant leſſe infant doeth ſmell yea draweth nouriſhment liuer vmbilicall veine naturall inſtinct child borne maketh chooſe mother milke nouriſhment odour ſmell milke ſee infant layde breaſt hee ſuddenly kinde naturall force lap tongue head breaſt ſuckes ſtrongly shall attribute work infant smell rather inſtinct nature meanes deceiue childe ſuckling bottle ſuch thing like nipple mother breaſt ſoone euer hee taſtes therein differ aliment naturally deſireth preſently cry appeaſed till haue mother breaſt againe thus much ſhall ſufficient haue ſpoken cauſes odour ſome difficulty coincident wee proceed difference qvest li difference odour diſtinguiſh particular kind difference odour giue proper name altogether impoſsible partly becauſe senſe dull partly becauſe owne ignorance beſt philoſophers haue difference odour nice beene aſhamed confeſſe wherefore thoſe haue written part philoſophy conſidering imperfect senſe make fitte diſtinctions obiect ſeeing wee ſmell nothing doeth vehemently goade affect senſe haue thought good diſtinguiſh kindes odour improperly way tranſlation difference sapours taſtes neither haue done without good ground sapours sauors name ſo nature great affinity analogy proportion inſomuch odour ſauour dependeth vpon ſapour taſte ſayth ariſtotle fift chapter booke de ſenſu ſenſili therefore referred taſt bode odoriferous hath alſo ſtrong taſte defining odoriferous able moue ſenſe ſmelling hath power diffuſe ſapide ſiccity ſayth therefore man ſhall eſteeme wit ayre water moyſt woulde followe odour bee nothing elſe nature ſapide ſiccity reciding moysture kind therefore odour fall vnder senſe theſe biting sweete sowre tart fat rotten ſmelles theſe ſayth ariſtotle place quoted kind odour proportionable bitter taſts becauſe bitter thing hardly ſwallowed ſo rotten ſtinking ſmels receiued senſe without kind regret loathing two difference odour firſt common bruite beaſts accident doeth mooue pleaſure paine thoſe odour together ſteame ariſe meat pleaſant thoſe hungry vnpleſant offenſiue ſuch ſatisfied kinde ſelfe pleaſant vnpleaſant ſmell breatheth flower proper men alone doe prouoke appetite leſſe rather another kinde ſatisfaction doe dull appeaſe yet wee muſt beleeue difference taſtes may applyed odour euer ſaid felt ſalt ſmell finally odour either naturall artificiall naturall odour thoſe naturally body artificiall ſuch apothecary vſe make pleaſure phyſicke commixtion many ſpices theſe call compound odour ſimple qvest lii medium meane smelling hath yet called queſtion whether ſmell ſtandeth need medium men taking granted medium required partly philoſopher opinion ſubſcribing axiome ſo often itterated v obiect immediatly touching inſtrument maketh senſation partly becauſe 97j text ſecond booke de anima ariſtotle ſpeaking particularly smell hath aſsigned thereto determinate medium meane place hee doth onely take away doubt whether senſe made medium withall declareth medium abſolued perfected therefore great reaſon alſo conſent odour hauing reſidence fumide exhalation exhalation odour exhaleth body vapour cannot accompany odour vnto confirmed medium smelling organ eſpecially diſtance thing great betwixt body odour iſſueth organ senſe muſt diſsipated vnleſſe preſerued ſome medium yet euen med • um doth ſo preſerue degree diſsipated vaniſheth away wee conclude therefore senſe smelling ſtandeth neede medium mediū ſhould ſaith plancentinus reſolued although ignorant philoſophers one conſent doe agree herein ariſtotle ſaith medium double wit ayre water concerning ayre without controuerſie medium smelling becauſe draw breath ſame time alſo smell beſide odour exhaleth ayre approued mixt body diffuſed dimentions way ayre diffuſed certaine ſigne ayre medium vehickle smels concerning water placentinus maketh ſome doubte although arist 2 booke de anima eſpecially 8 chap 4 booke de hiſtoria animalium doth ſtriue earneſtly proue fiſhes water true medium smelling foundation thoſe creature liue water smell ſo neceſſary muſt alſo medium wherein obiect ſhould tranſported medium water queſtioned ariſtotle cannot ayre ayre ſoone generated water doth exhale bubble vp ſame arist teacheth 5 chap booke de senſ et senſil whence concludeth fiſhes water muſt need medium truly conſequence certainely vndoubtedly good foundation ground wherevpon raiſeth true haue called queſtion adde one argument taken nature medium manner odom hath placentinus againſt exiſtence ſiccity therefore requireth alſo medium dry leaſt obiect ſhould looſe odour office medium conſerue obiect water moyſt way fit conſerue dry odour reſpect contrariety betwixt vnleſſe man ſo debaſed ſay one contrary medium vnto much ſhould affirme contrary doe mutually impugne cheriſh foſter one another seeing therefore water moyſt muſt needes extinguiſh diſſolue odour dry cannot poſsibly competent medium hence appeareth inualidity aristotle foundation wit fiſhes doe smell remaineth therefore ayre onely medium smelling qvest liii manner odour affecteth changeth medium great controuerſie amongſt maſters philoſophy odorable obiect doth change medium whether alteration reall intentionall auerhoes impugning auicen ſaith done intentionally colour made coloured hee reaſoneth manner odour ſhould bee tranſported ayre together body would penetration body impoſsible abſurd ſay auerhoes deceiued becauſe intentionall obiect cannot really moue senſe manifeſt smell really obiecteth concerning colour wee haue diſputed already precedent controuerſies adde hereto intentionall being produced soule doe depend thereon therefore called entia rationis notion reaſon conceſsion therefore would follow obiect vnderſtanding senſe true reall obiect make impreſsion intentionall odour medium auerhoes remember ruled axiom nihil eſt intellectu quod non prius fuerit senſu nothing mind firſt senſe purpoſe ſhould thing vnderſtanding remitted returned vnto senſe ſeeing thing therefore receiued senſe might attaine vnto vnderſtanding whereas auerhoes ſaith would penetration body odorable obiect really alter medium anſwer conſequence good ayre moſt liquid element doth eaſily yield body adde beſide afumid exhalation mingled ayre may caried recaried hither thither manner alſo opinion philoponus iandunus may bee refuted doe affirme odour may really together exhalation caried philoponus iandunus refuted good ſpace medium marry reſt medium attayneth vnto organ senſe altered onely intentionally odour reall doth alwayes worke really intentionall dependeth vpon vnderſtanding ſome part medium really changed part intentionally reaſon remote diſtances great tract medium really affected little diſtances moue obiect noſes little aegidius opinion odour really produced medium sound ſayth placentinus vtterly falſe ſo much colour ſimply alſo aegidius immediately made mixtion firſt quality poſsibly manner receiued ayre ſhall odour ſecond quality bee generated ayre furthermore ſecond quality cannot mutually worke one vpon another one white cannot produce another white one odour expireth breatheth body beget another odour medium cauſe alſo moſt diſclaime ammonius boetius ſay odour may paſſe one ſubiect another although proceede together exhalation ammonius boetius body ayre yet doth change ſubiect flit another ayre made vapoury ſuſtayneth exhalation together odour conſerueth vehickle vnto yet vapour diſsipated odour vaniſheth together therewith would happen fit flit mooue one ſubiect another wee therefore auicen doe reſolue medium really changed odour doth really yſſue mixed body haue proued whence auicen redeemed followeth neceſſarily ſome part medium wit vppon odoriferous exhalation doth immediatly worke really affected againe odour doe really medium really affected attaine euen vnto braine therefore queſtion medium really affected thoſe therefore ſay affected intentionally alſo thoſe confeſſe ſome part affected really part intentionally haue ſit downe beſide cuſhion although odour proceede really ſubiect reach really vnto braine yet man muſt conceiue odour diffuſed whole medium obiect euen vnto organ wafted vpon wing wind tranſported motion ayre odour attayneth really vnto braine may really affect braine proued becauſe ſuch odour ſometimes helpe ſometime hurt detriment ſeemeth proceed odour quality ſubiect accompanieth odour exhalation odour quality cannot haue hurtfull quality vnleſſe graunt quality bee quality neither doeth quality onely exhalation affect braine ſometimes ſome ſeedes confirmed ſtrange inſtance ſubſtance body ſubtle partes tranſported exhalation ſetling braine brings foorth fearefull accident ſtrange effect ſmelling oft vpon baſill scorpion bred braine therefore neceſſary science senſes ſhould beleeue odour really perceiued organ confirmation wherof wee may alſo adde argument becauſe knowledge ſcience hath originall senſes ſcience reall intentionall ſhall ſcience hath reall ſubiect take beginning senſes receiue nothing intentionall therefore manifeſt senſes doe perceiue obiects intentionally really conſequent medium alſo really affected may obiected odour really imprinted organ obiection neede externall medium beſide axiome falſe obiect vpon senſe doth make senſation grant indeed neede medium ſhould betwixt reall odour organ vſe medium conſeruation preparation solution tranſportation odour differ specie hee would neuer haue ſayd guſtus tactus quidam ſimply plainly guſtus tactus hee would haue ſayde taſt kinde touch taſt touch neither wee wonder ariſtotle ſpeakes firſt inſtance maner alphabet 〉 body aboundeth • ull victous riſhment vve therefore beleeue aristotle thus vnderſtood becauſe ſo oftentimes hee teſtifies sapor hath reſidence beeing humidity humid moyſt might alſo ſay ariſtotle ſpeaketh place sapour nouriſheth sapour guſtable quality doth nouriſh becauſe incorporeall third anſwer cannot turned body nouriſheth muſt neceſsity bee conuerted body nouriſhed therefore queſtion ariſtotle ſpake sopor meant de corpore sapido body without sapors taſtes indeede sapid body may nouriſh ſaith auicen vvhich auicen hath good taſte doth alſo nouriſh sapor taſte dooth nouriſh ſubſtance wherein sapor doth conſiſt manner alſo ariſtotle expounded hee ſaith touch fourth senſe aliment doth meane falleth vnder touch vnder taſte ſame manner ſame reſpect vnder touch regarde tactile quality vnder taſte regard sapor much therefore ſaide becauſe aliment body cannot found without tactile quality touch indeede perceiueth theſe quality perceyueth sapor sapour therefore 63 text third booke de anima hath ſaide touch senſe aliment explaineth himſelfe manner aliment bodie perceiued touch seeing therefore aliment bodie muſt haue tactile guſtale quality therefore may truely called obiect taſte touch yet obiect neither senſe aliment touch moyſt dry hard ſoft taſte ſweete bitter salt like reaſon alledge ariſtotle hold weight becauſe ariſtotle ſuch intention yet may grant moyſture perceiued fifte taſte moiſture ſapid inſapide moiſture moiſture without taſte may diſcerned senſe taſting vtterly deny concerning neceſsity vrge meerely friuolous ariſtotle ſupponeth touch ſimply neceſſary ſo creature without cannot ſubſiſt sixt taſte neceſſary touch becauſe kind touching yet denie taſte alſo neceſſary secundum quid ſay schooles ſelfe becauſe creature wanteth nouriſhment dooth therefore follow either taſt touch ſhould one elſe imputation ſhould caſt vpon ariſtotle contradicting himſelfe may alſo obiected becauſe taſte touch one obiection ſame tongue therefore ſhould one ſame senſe conſequence good organe senſe beſide proper facultie solution senſation alſo furniſhed senſe touching becauſe sēſe taſting alwaies found touching found faculty senſation conclude onely senſes taſte alſo diſtinct different senſe touch qvest lvii obiect tasting obiect taſte ſayth aristotle fourth chapter booke de senſu ſenſili onely euident manifeſt vnto v odour obiect taſt euident ſenſes alſo senſible obiects reaſon may giue ſame place aristotle becauſe taſte kinde touching senſe man perfect reſt obiect taſte guſtabile gustile wordeſignifieth two thing wit sapour quality affection ſeated ſapide body body ſelfe wherein sapour sapour proper adequated proportionable 2 ſignifications guſtabile obiect taſte therefore ariſtotle appropriateth word guſtabile sapour ſayth viſible eſt color ſic guſtabile eſt ſapor viſible colour ſo guſtile sapour ſhould ſay guſtable body way guſtile taſted onely reſpect sapour yet hee oftentimes put gustabile sapor reaſon becauſe sapour hath exiſtence ſelfe neyther moue senſe hath eſſence mixt body therfore calleth guſtabile mixt body reſpect quality called sapour guſtile may taſted sapour doeth ſelfe mooue senſe becauſe cannot ſubſiſt without mixt body conſidered euen without mixt body may ſayd obiect taſt becauſe alone mixt body moueth senſe qvest lviii matter sapours sapour quality ariſing firſt quality alone ſelfe able mooue taſte firſt quality two ſortes ſome ſapor 2 kindes firſt quality actiue heate cold others paſsiue moyſture drought actiue quality sapour hath efficient cauſe wit heate paſsiue materiall cauſe wit moyſture leaſt man ſhould wonder wee make moyſture nothing elſe incorporeall quality bee matter sapours anſwere wee vnderſtand humidity abſtract concrete haply proper ſay humidum humiditas ſay trueth sapour made onely humidity humidity ioyned ſiccity yet ſo humidity predominant wherefore ariſtotle ſayth sapour dwelleth moiſt odour sapours made ſimple humidity doth dry yet doth name humidity alōe ſimple ſiccity conioyned therefore hee rather expreſſeth himſelfe humidum siccum hamiditas ſiccitas ſo one moyſture preuaileth ouer ſiccity ſiccity ouer moyſture thus much doth aristotle intimate booke de ſenſu ſenſili ſayth vniuerſall nature sapour paſsion senſe taſting made earthy dry moyſt wherefore humidity predominant earthy ſiccity properly matter sapors may bee obiected sapours humidity muſt preuaile ouer ſiccity 1 obiection thoſe body wherein ſiccity preuailes ouer humidity ſhould inſipide without taſt many ſiccity predominant aſhes pepper ginger ſuch like yet notwithſtanding haue ſharpe quicke taſte adde moreouer true sapors ſhould properly belong vnto aliment 2 obiection ariſtotle ſayeth 28 text third booke de anima hunger appetite hot dry aliment therefore moyſt hotte dry becauſe appeaſeth hunger seeing therefore men confeſſe sapours doe properly belong aliment ſhould ſeeme alſo sapors haue reſidence moyſtur ſiccity vve anſwere actuall sapour ſuch sapour inſtantly fitte mooue taſte muſt neceſſarily bee moyſture obiect pepper aſhes ſuch like anſwere manner vvee grant themſelues inſipide haue sapour potentiall doe taſte till chewed accident humour perpetually remayneth mouth tongue prouoketh produceth potentiall vertue act becauſe ſiccity predominant therefore yeeld ſharpe quicke taſt add concerning aliment eaſily anſwered two kind aliment one ſatisfieth hunger another ſatisfieth thirſt ſatisfieth solution 2 2 kind aliment thirſt exceeding moyſt reſpect ſatisfieth hunger may bee called dry although doe follow ſhould ſimply dry yea neceſſary ſhould haue ſo much moyſture senſe taſting doth require otherwiſe could ſatisfie hunger finally wahtſoeuer mooueth taſt muſt neceſſitie haue inward moyſture wherein ſteeped although hath outward reaſon may melt diffuſe ſelfe organ senſe thoſe thing hard cannot bee diſſolued cannot mooue senſe taſting wee may conceiue rough torrified tongue ſuch ſee chopped blacke violent ague cannot make certaine eſtimation difference sapors qvest lix efficient cauſe sapours paſſiue quality therefore moyſture preuailing ouer siccity matter heate efficient cauſe sapor sapors actiue qualityes haue heate efficient cauſe ſimple pure element themſelues without ſapor odor ſo alſo mixt body ſuch thing would reſult euery element ſhould reſerue owne quality himſelfe therefore neede heate draw sapors concoction humidity siccity concoction theſe two fitly mixed one neither reaſon cold cannot man ſhould ſubſtitute cold office dayly experience teacheth v fruites frozen apple doe vtterly looſe taſt yea although thawed frozen fruit looſe taſt reſume former heate yet taſts doe returne cold ſo farre efficient cauſe taſt rather doth vtterly deſtroy adde hereto fruite attaineth natiue taſt till grow ripe ripening made heat remaineth therfore heate much concocteth humidity accompliſheth perfect mixtion true onely efficient cauſe sapors qvest lx number order sapors ariſtotle 4 chapter book de ſenſu ſenſili going recite diuers kind taſts compareth colour becauſe great affinty betwixt becauſe iuſt many one kinde concludeth vnder number ſeuen ſay eight kindes sapours plinie 21 chapter many kind sapors 15 booke reckons vp thirteene vve ariſtotle rather reduce vnto number ſeauen becauſe may indeede infinite variety mixtion ſo ſhould draw infinite difference sapors poſſible many mixture accurately number nothing ſo ſure difference sapors doe ariſe multiplicity mixtion example wherein heate moyſture aboundant ſweete sapour hote dry bitter ſalt sapor ſo reſt qualitie hath greater leſſe rule mixt body yet alwayes moyſture muſt haue firſt place inſtance haue place galen ſixth ſeuenth eight chapter fourth booke de ſimplicium medicamentorum facultatibus fruites tree elegant place galen concerning sapors ſaith hee appeare v ſweete ripe ſoure young conſistence proceſſe time become moyſt ſowrnes turnes ſharpeneſse ſharpeneſſe looſe degree grow ripe length become ſweete among theſe sapors salt bitter contrary ſweete becauſe vnder salt bitter contrary ſweet ſame kind greateſt diſtance betwixt ariſtotle hauing reſpect white blacke calleth priuatiues without good cauſe although beeing vnder ſame kinde differ moſt one another yet cannot bee truely ſayde bee contraryes ſweetneſſe generated ſubiect fulfilled heate moiſture ſalt bitter ſubiect hot yet dry therefore ſweete sapor nouriſheth reſt yea thinke sapors doe nouriſh onely sweet nouriſheth reaſon ſweetneſſe lurketh ſecret bowel ſapide body although taſt cannot ſo manifeſtly perceiued nouriſhment muſt bee conuerted bloode ſo may become fit nouriſhment vnto part laudable good blood hot moyſt ſweete taſte sapor therefore vvhich hath greateſt analogy affinity bloode fitteſt nouriſh ſuch ſweete taſte sapors haue ſweetneſſe al altogether vnfit nouriſhment ſome thinke ſweete bitter extreme sapors grounding themſelues vpon plato timaeo becauſe ſay thoſe sapors bee accounted extreames come neereſt vnto firſt quality neyther ſweete bitter ſweete bitter extreame sapors argument ſuch styptick binding keene keene taſte byting ſuch pepper reſulteth high degree heate bindeth contracteth tongue ariſeth extreme cold againe thoſe obiects extreme hurt offend inſtrument ſweet doth hurt refreſheth yea conſerueth temper thereof acceptable pleaſure delight another reaſon may bee ſweete extreme taſte becauſe ſowre keene paſſage ſweete whatſoeuer keene biting ripe ſowre greene haue kinde ſweeteneſſe come perfection quality tranſition mediate meane quality extreame therefore bee concluded ſweete bitter ſowre keene extreame sapors although muſt need confeſſe theſe argument haue ſome life ſtrength yet preſume ariſtotles opinion may well bee maintained true indeede refuced conſider sapors according originall reſult firſt quality aduerſaries haue concluded well regard sapor without reſpect vnto originall ſimply sapours naked quality mooue taſte aduerſaries wrong may well plato vnderſtood matter manner text ſecond booke de anima ſaith ariſt toucht vpon taſte hath externall medium becauſe kinde touching ſelfe hath ſuch medium beſide hath nothing matter notwithſtanding wil aduenture put forth ſelues frankly exhibite sapours againe greater argument bee fleſh ſhould bee organ taſting becauſe ſpongy taſte neuer made vnleſſe moyſture carrieth sapour bee imbibed organ taſting purpoſe nothing ſo fit ſpongy pulpe tongue moreouer senſes double therefore nature though ſhe great reaſon make tongue ſingle commodity voyce ſuch circumſtances wee haue particularized hiſtory yet might ſort double ſhe hath drawne line middeſt whereby diuided right ſide left manner part mouth diuided mouth senſe taſte therefore muſt belong onely toung qvest lxiii whether tongue alone taſte wee hauce prooued fleſh pulp tongue true inſtrument taſting notwithſtanding doubted whether action belong onely part may alſo communicated vnto others may communicated part ſome argument vrged firſt may communicated taſte kinde touching touching diffuſed thorough body may ſeeme therefore taſte alſo diffuſed thorough part one eſpecially ſo farre meate doeth attayne mouth gullet stomacke againe yſſueth braine ſoft nerue ſimple ſingle originall hath paced little forward skull diuided two branch whereof one inſerted tongue lower part thirdly ſee stomacke doeth reiect caſt vp ſome meates vomit embraceth contayneth like manner gullet ſwallowes ſome meates well freely others without loathing much difficulty yea ſome meates becauſe enmity betwixt ſtomack taſte euen downe caſt vp againe may therefore demaunded choyce bee made difference faculty whereby wee heare faculty whereby wee ſmell faculty whereby wee taſte difference ariſeth diſpoſition organ foote would ſee elbow would heare ſides would ſmel crowne would taſt theſe part wer diſpoſition receiue obiects theſe senſes like manner although gullet stomack receiue ſoft nerue yet gullet stomacke taſte becauſe diſpoſed thereto reaſon nature hath giuen ſoft nerue wee may exquiſite stomacke beſide membranous hath infinite number branch nerues inſerted thereinto wonder kicke againſt leaſt offence thruſt finger throat wee procure vomit ſtomack caſts vp ſome meat reteins wee make stomacke loath thing becauſe tactile quality doe vrge prouoke ſenſible part vvee alſo may ſay becauſe contiguity part stomacke forewarned tongue ſo tongue perceiuing anie horrid vnpleaſant ſauour communicateth senſation ſtomacke forewarning approaching enemy thereupon ſtirring vp ſelfe battell yerketh againſt caſteth forth ſay true ſuch inſtinct nature bred another anſwere argument ſetled thoſe part wee may attribute ſenſe taſting gullet stomacke becauſe theſe partes taſte ſicke man take pill bole wrapt vp sugar wuold neuer retaine take without sugar hee preſently caſts vp reaſon becauſe rowled sugar otherwiſe made ſweete bitter vnpleaſant sapor perceyued tongue warning thereof ſwallowing pils giuen stomacke reteyned ſweetened becauſe ill taſte obſcured ſo tongue deceyued arriued gullet stomack although sugar melt yet caſt vp againe becauſe ſtomack doth perceiue sapor reaſon would let vnſauoury thing ſtomacke endeuour touch tongue neceſsity leaſt ſhould alone creature man hath two feete dwell vpon earth vſe feete onely hath two feete anſwereable two hand ſtood groueling foure ſtiltes could hee ride write build throw weapon exerciſe thoſe art wherewith furniſhed figure poſture bruite beaſts beene altogether vnprofitable incommodious diuine creature neither could haue looked vppe heauen cauſe euen anaxagoras could ſay created ſit meditate ſay ſitting ſoule wiſest neither could paſſe ſharpe vnequall ſloping place climbe turret builde houſes ſuch thing true feete ſwifter creature thing equall neede man ſuch footemanſhip ouertake induſtry hee able circumuent creature therefore made bipes two foot therefore ſtandeth vpright ſitteth pleaſure proper vſe foote walke action walking therefore office foote foot called inſtrumentum ambulatorium walking inſtrument walking vvhen one legge reſteth vpon ground brought forward reſting action foote properly ſo called reach forwarde action legge therefore ſeeing ambulation made ſtation muſcle hath ioyned vnto companion nay rather emulus concurrent aduerſary becauſe author motion contrary example euery flexor bending muſcle hath tenſor extending muſcle euery adductor moueth toward hath abductor moueth froward note euery leuator lifting muſcle hath depreſſor ſinking muſcle vvhen therfore muſcle contracted alſo extended extention followeth motion antagonist aduerſary ſo extētion proper motion muſcle contracted rather paſsion action third motion muſcle yet improper neither contracted relaxed falleth weight called tranſlation decidence ſinking motion soule elementary fourme part illuſtrated beames animall ſpirite falleth owne weight ſo part moued mouing faculty reſt galen ſayth trembling commeth tremor trembling common people cal ſhaking palſey commeth paſſe equal contention ſtrife betweene moouing facultie moued member faculty lifteth member vp waight member ſinketh ſelfe ſo viciſsitude enterchange lifting vp falling commeth trembling laſt motion muſcle call tonicall wherein fibre muſcles laſt motion tonicall ſtreatched ſo remaine ſo part ſeemeth indeed bee immouable yet trueth really moued motion moſt euident bird flye glide ayre wing ſtiffe ſtreatched ſeeming immouable man alſo ſtandeth example tonicall motion motion ſo piſmire moueth vpward vpon ſtaffe faſt ſtaffe deſcendeth downward motion galen ſpeaketh hee ſayeth euen ſleepe muſcles doe moue therefore foure motion muſcles two performed themſelues thoſe contraction conſeruation contracted 2 motion perſe ſecond motion cal tonicall ſuch nature ſucceſſiues ſucceeding motion leſſe accompliſhed conſerued firſt made two contrary former accident wit extention decidenſe contraction extention tonical motion haue ſometimes extream ſometimes 2 per accidens middle figure poſtures extreame poſitions painefull thoſe meane eaſie pleaſant extreame wee cannot long endure vnleſſe wee bend minde power vnto meane eaſily endure wee thinke therefore whileſt ſleepe rarely ſuffer extreame flection extentions muſcles onely fancy worketh exceeding ſtrongly otherwiſe muſcles inclined rather bent either ſide hippocrates obſerueth prognoſtico lye ſayth hee ſleepe thighes handes feete moderately reflected inclined becauſe time strength animall action ceaſed abated men alſo ſleepe haue ſo ſtrong tonnical motion awake may perceiue ſphincter muſcles ſhut vp way excrement perfourme indeede tonnicall motion good ſound ſleepe violence excrement great either ceaſe motion ſo excrement auoydeth elſe faculty diſtreſſed calleth helpe ſo party awaketh becommeth able hould owne worthy opening mouth muſcle ſaith galen 1 book de diſſect anuſculorum firſt al thoſe begin afflicted conuulſions intended ſtretched whence come thoſe conuulſions call cynicke doggeſpaſmes becauſe contraction theſe men doggeſpaſme conſtrained writh grinne like dogges fibre muſcle galen firſt booke de anatom adminiſt counſelleth chirurgion well aduiſed becauſe inciſions ſometimes neceſſary part ignorant chyrurgions knowing courſe haue large tranſuerſe ſections deuided ſo farre cheekes haue flowne upward skin vnderneath muſcle called buccinator either becauſe maketh cheeke called bucca trumpeter ta 6 booke de vſupartium ſecond de diſſec muſ theſe muſcles yet would haue foure eight ſeuerall motion effected foure oblique two lip beſide foure right two altogether right eight ſeuerall motion theſe lip muſcle either ſide alone work motion made ſidelong bee ſtretched ſhall ſame lip one ſame manner drawne vpward vpper muſcles downward lower thus galen exemplifieth vſe theſe muſcles place laſt aboue named deſires ſatisfaction may haue recourſe wee follow ſtory theſe muſcles deſcribed fleſhy rude lumpe ta 7 fig 3 c yet corrall lippes muſculous may added circumference mouth maketh lip aboue ſome made peculiar paire muſcles face call pleaſe corral lip falopius diuideth two muſcles wherof one garniſheth vpper lip lower aſcribeth muſcles vſe corrall ſeuerall motion gathering wrinkling themſelues vp fleſh lippes would make mouthes little chap xv muſcles lower iaw two iawes vpper well man creature immooueable excepting parrot crocodile lower neceſſarily mooued breaking preparing meate articulation voyce parot crocadile moueth vpper iaw motion lower iaw two kindes ſimple compound ſimple motion ſixe compound one ſixe ſimple motion vpward downeward right hand left foreward backewards compound motion made right left forward backeward whereby iawes ſeemeth bee carryed round motion vpward sixe ſimilar motion performed temporall muſcle downeward digaſtricke right hand left firſt grinder called manſorius primus backeward manſorius muſcle lurketh mouth forward fifth paire motion vpward downeward bite ſhare cut motion ſides whether right hand left forward backeward grind vſe theſe motion meate falleth vpon teeth lower iaw vppon moouing ſtone mill mill weight vpper ſtone breaketh corne vppon lower ſo meate ground betweene vpper teeth reſemble fixed immoueable ſtone booke ſeuenth chapter muſcle hath 3 nerues either ſide inſerted two third coniugation third harder fift coniugation giue greater ſtrength nerues harder muſcle hath ſtronger performe action maruell tongue hardly imagined accompliſhed ſo ſo ſmall muſcles determine end ſubſtance tongue wherefore theſe may called common muſcles tongue hyois certaine nerues diſtributed ſixt coniugation chap xviii muſcles tongue tongue hath three end nature ſpeake taſte rowle meate mouth cannot bee performed without motion therefore nature hath allotted vnto muſcles thoſe three action may bee called three vſes tongue talker taſters rowlers meate man eſpeciall end creation tong motion ſame ſpeech beaſts taſt becauſe want hand wherwith reach meat • vnto taſt neceſſary ſhould able tongue lick gather earth man eſpecially vſe man able taſt without motion tong becauſe hath hand wherewith bring would taſt vnto inſtrument organ ſence haue neceſſary vſe rowling returning meat againe vnto teeth falleth ſpace mouth vvherefore might anſwer thoſe intention made moueable therfore muſcles muſcles onely alſo figure fit motion ſome part thinner yet becauſe ſhould moue beyond teather nature hath reſtrained ligament body reaſon diuers fibre bridle tongue infinitely diſpoſed motion agitation might rowle vpon axletree turne vpon thoſe hinge onely thoſe thing haue ſpoken ſufficiently heretofore excepting left hand ſides ſubſtance toung worke ſucceſſiuely one vpon another turne tongue round theſe motion muſcles boue hyois little ſome rather aſcribe fibrous ſubſtance tongue hath indeed three kindes fibre roote tongue theſe muſcles remooued appeareth glardulous fleſh roote certaine fleſh compounded many glandules mingled fat fleſh doeth merrit name muſcle becauſe muſcle doeth conſiſt glandules kernelles fleſhy fibre tab 8 fig 1 2 h knot glandules groweth roote tongue liquor might alwaies bee kept moyſte becauſe without moyſture perfect taſte concoction stomack without elixation boyling concoction stomacke roaſting boyling elixation therefore nature hath ordained glandulous pancreas sweetbread touch stomacke thence might continually aſcend moyſt vapour concoction ſtomacke might accompliſhed moyſte boyling dry roaſting moreouer moyſture kernelly fleſh maketh motion toung glib glad wee ſay nimble tongue dry vvee may perceiue thoſe exceedingly thirſt motion ſlovv ſame alſo vvee haue experience thoſe labour burning ague vvhome moyſture tongue exhauſted dryed vp moreouer almond throate call tonſilla obſerued yeilding perpetuall moyſture doe moiſten tongue ſo motion chap xix muſcles larynx throttle becauſe action throttle larynx perfourmed voluntary action muſcle contraction motion nature hath giuen muſcles action contraction might bend extend moue ſidelong ioynts griſtles ſo glottis tounglet might become mouable cleft might made broader narrower need ſhould require ſo behoued becauſe conuenient voice well ſpeach ſhould commaund throttle therefore hath two kindes muſcles common proper common ſixe three paire foure doe conſtringe two dilate common 3 paire common ſo called becauſe ariſe partes implanted throttle theſe wee treate firſt becauſe firſt fall vnder view ſo come firſt ſhewen firſt paire common muſcles tab 9 fig 7 xx veſalius diuers others firſt paire make ſecond ſituated forepart throttle one ſide call bronchios weazon muſcles becauſe cleaue rough artery along called 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 hippocrates ariſe fleſhy broade beginning vpper inner part breaſtbone iugulum aboue clauicles right ſibres doe runne vp along weazon fleſhy little broader aroſe inſerted ſides ſhield griſtle called thyroeis neare glandules broade fleſhy tendon man one beaſts deuided middeſt moſt one part faſtned throttle bone hyois yet galen opinion originall inſerted breſtbone long becauſe ſnieldgriſtle thyroides whole larynx moued eſpecially baſe voice throttle mooueth downeward whole weazon contracted membranous diſtances therefore paire cleaueth whole length moreouer ſlender becauſe throttle eaſily deſcending waight require great ſtrength yet notwithſtanding haue certaine inſcriptions neruous diſtinctions ſuch right muſcles paunch length tenuity ſecured danger vſe draw ſhieldgriſtle called thyroides conſtringe contract ſo dilate cleft fiſſure glottis tounglet baſe voice alſo doe ſomewhat contract weazon doubled wee ſpeake throttle much dilated aboue ſecond paire common muſcles ta 9 fig 3 h veſalius cals firſt paire 2 paire alſo doth falopius ſome others ſituated likewiſe forepart larynx throttle called hyoeides rather hyothyroeides ſhieldbone muſcles theſe oppoſed former farre ſhorter ariſe broad fleſhy almoſt lower part bone hyois whoſe inward ſides ſeeme continuated right fibre creepe downeward together ſauing inner ſides doe depart one another implanted broad oblique end lower part griſtle thyroeides wholly couer vſe dilate lower part ſhieldgriſtle contract vpper drawing throttle vpward make cleft ſhorter excepting ſometimes firſt ſecond thinke falopius haue originall vſe alſo thought bend necke foreward doth firſt paire one thing peculier ſaith veſalius platerus conſenteth haue throughpaſſage veines artery run arme 3 paire third paire veſalius maketh third paire back platerus third paire necke called tranſuerſales two ouerthwart muſcles tab 11 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſeate backe ariſe rootes tranſuerſe proceſſes ſixe vppermoſt rackebones cheſt whence degree become ſtronger thicker inſerted outſide tranſuerſe proceſſes bone necke rarely firſt sometimes haue two original one ſecond paire muſcles backe fift paire cheſt together make vp theſe muſcles vſe worke together extend directly backeward one alone motion direct oblique alſo betweene theſe paſſe thoſe nerues marrow backe come rackebones necke fourth paire called spinati becauſe ſeated among ſpines vertebra 4 paire tab 12 π occupy take vp whole necke ariſe rootes ſpines ſeuen vppermoſt bone cheſt haue attained lowermoſt vertebra necke gather broader originall therefrom yet fibre receiued frō vertebra cheſt indeuour obſcure inſertiō quaint paſſages ſpine lowermoſt vertebra grow ſtrongly reſt ſpines necke bone draw new beginning rootes tranuerſe proceſſes euen ſecond vertebra inſert fibre receiue ſpine racke bone next aboue till haue implanted themſelues ouer ſpine ſecond racke bone necke right ioyned left indeede ioyne along progreſſe vp necke ſauing ſpines bone peepe vp betweene ſeuer little aſunder fibre originall outward aſcend incline inward vſe worke together extend necke drawing directly backward infraſpinatus doe moue arme ſemicircularly backward ſayth perfect circular motion arme hath peculiar muſcle ſucceſsiue working circular compoū ded right oblique notable muſculous portion ariſing proceſſe bladebone like anchor inſerted arme arantius placentinus doe eſteeme muſculous portion bee muſcle arme others account firſt muſcle cubit vſe ſay leade arme proceſſe bladebone indeede motion arme cubit neare kinne cubit bent elbow moſt neceſſary arme alſo ſhould lifted vp may obſerue ſelues ſo much muſcles arme chap xxv muſcles cubit cubit ſecond part hande large acceptation conſiſteth two bone firſt called cubitus vlna cubite bone cubite ell retaine name call place bent elbow ſecond bone called radius wand theſe bone haue diuers motion therefore muſcles ell wand diuers cubit ell hath two motion bent extended directly galen attributeth alſo oblique motion columbus ſaith neuer bee founde manithe radius wand mooued turnes hand vpward downward firſt ſpeake motion cubite perfourmed helpe foure muſcles ſome ſay fiue theſe called muſcles cubite becauſe ſeated cubit becauſe mooue ariſe arme blade take vp roome along arme two bender inſide foreſide two three extenders outſide backeſide theſe muſcles ſeated cubit ſelfe ſerue mooue eyther wand vvreſt finger firſt bender called biceps tab 18 fig 1 2 3 tabl 10 fig 1 2 1 bender doubleheaded muſcle becauſe hath double beginning theſe ſtrong ſtanding one another giue way nerue arme inſertion muſcles ſame theſe original doe ariſe ſhoulderblade couered ſecond muſcle arme called deltoides tab 18 fig 1 fig 3 n vncouered extention chap xxix ſubſtance commeth betweene skinne palme finger tendon betwixt tendon skinne palme inner ſide finger appeareth certaine fleſhy ſubſtance like vnto far ſhall amiſſe little diſcourſe although whitiſh colour hath hardnes reſemble fat fleſh yet conceiue may fitly referred kinde fleſh well becauſe full ſinewy fibre alſo becauſe many ſmall threddy veines diſſeminated therethrough add alſo though man neuer ſo much extenuated conſumed yet alwaies remaines ſome part ſubſtance whereupon galen cals fleſh arabian thought kinde ſimple fleſh different body muſcle may fleſh fat obiected come ſo hard anſwere contaction bone neruous part lie vpon therefore like fat ioyneth vpon ioynts bone vſe ſubſtance pillow bed whereon many propagation ſinews might lie ſoft deriued greater nerues muſcle together ſecond muſcle vnder might ſecurely paſſe along length finger holdeth faſt leaſt ſhould depart owne ſeate ſo decline tranſuerſe ligament owne finger againe contracted ſhould ſtrut ariſe neither reſpiration bee performed cheſt moueth without motion followeth therefore cheſt muſt need moued reſpiration ſake demanded reſpiration ſo neceſſary anſwere becauſe high great heat heart ayre attracted reſpiration refrigerated cooled euen man face summer cooled fan wafteth freſh ayre vnto cheſt moued either ſelfe accident followeth motion ſpine rackbones backe backe bent cheſt alſo bent book de diſſect muſcul becauſe theſe muſcles cannot meanes truely ſeparated either muſt bee ſo many payres rackebones elſe muſt ſay one paire offering tedinous diſtributions vertebra payre one muſcle haue experience mutuall action paſsion interpoſition reſt middle figure yet notwithſtanding theſe muſcles spine except bending muſcles necke haue antagoniſts contrary becauſe inner region cheſt loynes part holybone ſpine faſtened haunchbones alſo frō trāſuers proceſſes root ſpines rackbones loines ta 29 ♌ pleaſe ſay fallop aſcend frō theſe proceſſes increaſt diuers original alſo rack cheſt threefold originall one higher end tranſuerſe proceſſe another lower roote ſame proceſſe third ſpines racke bone ſo ſeeme bee three kind muſcles mixed together one outward hauing long fibre another inward hauing ſhort third hauing yet ſhorter ariſeth ſpines originall grow brode degree intermination acute made ſpine twelfth ſometimes eleuenth ſponder cheſt become termination vſe ſlenderer fibre run obliquely vpward inward vſe worke together contract fibre extend part ſpine faſtened one alone worke extendeth part backe obliquely putteth body one ſide ſemicircular forme fourth paire called semiſpinati tab 10 11 29 25 ω ariſe acute originall originall ſpine twelfth rackebone ſometimes eleuenth cheſt ariſing vpward degree grow thicke fleſhy eſpecially ſpine fifth racke cheſt intertexed wouen neruous fibre imbrace ſpines rackes ſame preſently become attenuated termination fibre doe determine acute end ſpine firſt rackebone cheſt fibre moſt right theſe muſcles alſo former paire fill vp diſtances betwixt ſpines contigual touch one another nothing beſide membranous ligament iſſuing vpper ſpine lower commeth betweene vſe gather together ſpines whereinto inſerted extend lift vp part backe grow backe properly called dorſum vſe together muſcles loynes vnmoued vvhen one onely worketh mooueth backe ſide eight muſcles conſpire together whole backe bowed directly downeward foure worke together ſo one follow another mooue ſemicircle muſcles one ſide work alone body inclined ſide thus much muſcles backe chap xxxvi muſcles fundament bladder teſticles yard becauſe man politique creature made action contemplation fit ſhould either receiue nouriſhment auoyde excrement perpetually plant doe owne choyce therefore chop muſcles ſeruing diglutition ſwallowing ſo end gut outlet vrine muſcles ſet porter interclude paſſage vnleſſe liſt open muſcles therfore fundament foure two sphincter two leuators ſpincters one ſpincters fleſhy ta 30 fig 1 • ariſing lower rack holy bone like footeſteps alſo doe inſiſt calling artery 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſo veſſels beeing diſtinct name alſo diſtinct furthermore veſſels diſtinguiſhed ſtructure motion vſe veines artery differ ſtructure becauſe veine hath thin coate whereas coate artery thicke motion becauſe artery mooued perpetually conſpicuouſly diaſtloe ſyſtole dilation contraction whereas veine altogether becauſe blood attaineth vtmoſt elaboration perfection heart let v come definition veine veine may conſidered two manner wayes either similar originall part galen 2 booke de elementis account similar indeed two conſiderations veine yet leaſt according iudgement ſenſe againe booke de morborum differentiis proueth organical hee calleth veines artery muſcles organ firſt kinde moſt ſimple organ regard veine similar part muſt define temper temper forme ſimilarity may ſo ſpeake cold drie part generated ſlimy following portion ſeed ſayde cold reſpect naturall temper otherwiſe contaction blood figure organ whereby veine diſtinguiſhed nerue nerues haue onely pore ſenſible cauities praxagoras therefore error ſo thoſe follow call nerues vena continuatas continued veines explication definition ſimple thin coate noteth ſtructure veſſell diſcriminateth putteth difference betwixt veine artery artery hath double coate one outward another inward may beleeue erophilus fiuefold thicker veine becauſe containeth thinner ſpryghtfull blood concluded ſhut vp within thicke wals would eaſily breake priſon vaniſh away ſimple coate hath fibre kindes right oblique tranſuerſe owne priuate nouriſhment attracting retayning expelling faculty ſeruiceable yet cōmon vſe retayn draw blood treaſure nature neighbour veynes tranſmit ſame one another ſo make diſtribution finaly ſeparate pure impure thinke alſo ſayth laurentius fibre ordayned ad 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 auoyde inconuenience becauſe oftentimes blood aboundeth quantity offereth kinde violence veynes sometime right ſometime oblique ſometime tranſuerſe extentions veynes ſtood neede kindes fibre might bee ſo extended according violent occurſions impreſſions made blood otherwiſe would certaynly broken theſe fibre firſt moſt ſimple truly ſolyd particle veine ſubſtance filleth vppe ſtuffeth ſpaces betwixt fibre called fleſhy analogy proportion fibre veyne ſayth galen ſecond booke de temperamentis colder skin fleſh commeth betwixt hotter hence appeareth coate veyne differs much nature membrane peritoneum rimme bell pleura compaſſeth rib periosteon immedyatly inueſteth bone theſe indeed ſimple hauing ſeparated fibre may borne diuided euery way paper may coate veynes diſsimilar becauſe hath fibre fleſh proper coate veines inueſted oftentimes another called common common coate veines coate borroweth neighbour partes pleura veines cheſt doe borrow rimme thoſe lower belly ſaid haue often common coate veines haue example thoſe ſpinkled thorough ſome bowell thoſe wander body muſcles finally thoſe inſerted part broade veines ſayth hee haue alſo broade bellyes broade bone becauſe blood veines diuided whole body may well make eſtimation plenty temper bloode amplitude ſtraytneſſe veynes haue much blood eſteemed hollow gate veynes rootes theſe veynes confuſedly ſprinkled fleſh liuer yet ſo many moe rootes gate veyne hollow ſide liuer fewer gibbous conuex contrary many moe rootes hollow veyne runne gibbous surcles lower part yſſue three branch firſt called epiplois dextra ta 2 l right kell veine ſlender veſſell epiplois dextra deriueth surcles downeward right ſide lower membrane kell collicke gut gut tyed backe meſentery ſome part alſo colon ſelfe dogges veine ſpleenicke braunch vnto collicke gut third called pancreae table 2 many ſmall capillary veines run pancrea betwixt two kell veines well arterie wee 3 ſorts artery ſpake ſixt booke called venall arterie alſo wee ſpake hiſtory heart third called great artery ſubiect diſcourſe time wee conſider therefore similar organicall ſimilar arterie ſimilar may bee defined colde dry part engendred ſlimy part seede colde owne nature euent moſt hot reſpect bloode ſpirits therein contayned drie leſſe drie tendon dry nerue againſt may bee obiected galen ſecond booke ad glauconem ſayth neruous part require drying arteriall therfore dryer obiection solution anſwer neruous part place doth vnderſtand nerues properlie ſo called neruous body ligament tendon wee conſider artery organicall part may ſayde common inſtrument bodie long rounde fiſtulated compounded two peculiar coates intertexed wouen fibre receyuing contayning bloode vitall organical spirit laboured permixtion blood aire left ventricle hart alſo conueyeth vnto part bodie together heat ſuſtayne life ſubſtance thereof membranous neruous might better diſtended ſubſtauee compreſſed conformation neceſſary artery vein becauſe motion coat one outward thin rare ſoft like coate veyne wouen many right fibre ſome oblique none tranſuerſe another inward fiuefolde coat thicker broken alſo full tranſuerſe fibre better diſtribute blood vitall ſpirit whole body action motion inner coate onely artery hath theſe tranſuerſe fibre theſe two coat galen addeth third fift chapter ſeauenth booke de adminiſtrationibus anatom ſome ſay produced coate heart inner ſurface veſſell much like cobweb moſt conſpicuous production greateſt artery moreouer receyue common fine membrane lower belly rim cheſt pleura couereth firmeth tyeth neighbourparts yet thoſe artery run bowel haue coat great artery ſometime called ſimply great ſometime greateſt ſometimes thicke artery ſometime aorta indeed mother reſt artery great artery except rough artery venall vmbilicall artery like trunk body tree branch yſſue engendred ſaith bauhine galen de formatione foetus heart formed hath one principle originall ſeede immediately made beeing engendred original ſame time ſpermaticall part another diſpenſation radication heart left ventricle thereof yſſueth patent open orifice whereby receyueth heart acception word among phiſitians name nerues kind manifould erotianus thinketh hippocrates vſed word 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſortes veſſels veines artery nerues galen firſt booke de motu muſculorum beginning booke de oſsibus many place maketh three kindes nerues appeare without bloud without hollownes theſe nerues ſome proceede bone others muſcles others deriued brayne ſpinall marrow thoſe yſſue auicen cals latores cadger language theſe hippocrates wrote booke de locis homine whole body full nerues throughout whole body nerues doe run braine spinall marrow book de arte calleth meteor fleſh becauſe ſprinkled fleſh muſcles galen firſt book de motu muſculorum compareth theſe three kinde nerues among themſelues manner ligament inſenſible voluntary nerue moſt compared together exquiſite senſe tendon middle nature altogether inſenſible becauſe hath ſome filament ſtrings nerues therein neyther yet ſo quicke senſe nerue alſo many part body becauſe ſimilitude betwixt nerues called neruous although cannot bee referred theſe three kind ſo ſay wombe bladder gut neruous alſo vreters paſſages choller eiaculatory veſſelles place take deſcription anerue name nerue properly organ animall ſpirit faculty floweth whole body nature organ may thus deſcribed common inſtrument body like chord white round long without cauity ſenſe diſcerne vnleſſe bee optickes porous ſome vnited greater nerue made vp many ſmall ſtrings carrying canale motion conducted animall ſpirit braine marrow thereof vnto thoſe part body capeable ſenſe motion ſubſtance white marrowy much like marrow braine ſubſtāce take originall account marrow braine backe bee one ſame ſubſtance compact faſter neceſſary braine ſhould ſoft becauſe receiue ſpecies formes ſenſible thing much nerue deſcendeth lower ſeparated brain ſo much doth become harder might better able endure outward iniuries inueſted double membrane produced two meninges membrane membrane braine vtter whereof thicker produced dura mater whoſe office ſafegard defend marrow nerue conſiſt many ſmall chord threds ioyneth altogether hath encompaſſed receiueth branch neighbourveines inner membrane thinner much lyeth next vnto marrowe ſubſtance nerue ariſeth pia mater hath exquiſite ſenſe touching ſaith fernelius communicateth part whereinto nerue inſerted fernelius braine couered theſe two membrane ſo alſo nerues throughout whole body nerue nothing elſe indeede production braine threefold ſubſtance nerue falopius hath obſeruations bauhine may better diſtinguiſhed reaſon ſenſe anatomy able ſhew difference betwixt harde ſoft membrane nerue except optickes ſubſtaunce middeſt center nerue principall part thereof performeth action ſenſatiue motiue faculty conuayed braine vnto part coates marrow hence ſaith chiefe part galen cut aſunder marrow nerue preſently part nerue inſerted depriued ſenſe motion membrane ſame office vnto nerue braine nerues properlie inſtruments ſenſe motion immediate organ motion muſcle like pipe whole ſenſatiue ſoule faculty thereof ſenſe motion led guidance animall ſpirit brayne vnto part body ſtand neede either ſenſe motion therefore phyſitians vſe call organ ſenſe motion communicate vnto thoſe part inſerted either ſenſe alone onely motion together part hath ſenſe voluntary motion without nerue nerue belongeth part compreſſed intercepted cut aſunder corrupted ſenſe motion part doth ſodainly periſh hence ariſtotle alſo remembreth third booke de hiſtoria animalium nerue organ senſe part body hath ſtupor dulneſſe palſie reſolution ſpaſme convulſion hath nerue ſtupor diminution ſenſe palſie priuation ſenſe motion convulſion motion involuntary againſt willes galen third fift chapter ſixteenth booke de vſu partium ſayeth reaſon ſoftnes hardreſſ nerue thoſe nerues made voluntary motion hard thoſe made ſenſe ſoft ſofte nerues make ſenſation hard motion nay goeth eight chapter 7 booke de adminiſtrationib anatom affirmeth ſoft nerues onely fit ſenſe vnfit motion conceiue without great reaſon ſoftneſſe hardnes nerue diuerſly occaſioned firſt ſubſtance whereout yſſue ſo firſt nerues ſaide ariſe braine ſofteſt thoſe harder ariſe ſpinall marrow thoſe hardeſt ariſe marrow contained rackebones loines holybone secondly reſpect production ſo thoſe nerues ſoft run little way iourney ſcul wheras thoſe led vnto muſcles harder originall like manner thoſe run anfractuouſly turning winding hard branch third paire braine againe thoſe hard p • ſſe thorough hard body ſurcle fift coniugation creepeth hole galen opiniō templebone ancient called coecum blindehole made harder contaction bone beginning galen attributeth cauſe hardneſſe ſoftneſſe counſell nature becauſe ſaith inſtrument senſe needed ſoft nerue nerue canale leade along animall ſenſatiue ſpirit ſoft nerue becauſe affected ſuffer ſomwhat ſenſible obiect applying vnto without nowe becauſe ſoft fitter paſsion hard action therefore ſaith neceſſary inſtruments ſenſes ſhould haue ſofte nerues communicated vnto part mooued voluntary motion ſhould haue harder nerues hee prooueth becauſe vnto thoſe inſtruments ſenſe haue ſenſation motion double kind nerue communicated one senſe anotehr motion wee ſee eye vnto firſt coniugation allowed senſe ſecond motion ſo tongue receiueth third fourth coniugations ſo anatomiſts vſually diſtinguiſh taſting ſeuenth motion way hence appeareth nerues beſide vſe haue alſo animall action bauhines opinion reaſons becauſe affected obiect therefore ſofter nerues fitter senſe harder motion notwithſtanding ſaith bauhine yet wee conceiue nerues owne nature indifferently diſpoſed ſenſe motion ſo may called sentientes motores perceiuers mouers inſtruments part vnto conducted diſſeminated inſerted inſtruments motion muſcles called motorij moouing nerues inſtruments senſe called senſorij perceyuing nerues yea ſee one ſame nerue doth conuey inſtance motion ſenſe according diuerſity inſtruments example ſeuenth coniugation braine conueyeth vnto membrane bowel middle lower belly senſe touching yet ſame paire eyther ſide reflected make recurrent nerue diſtributeth ſurcles euerie muſcle larynx throttle mooue ſame ſame nerues ſhoulde meete inſtruments seeing hearing taſting ſame perceiuing moouing nerues would alſo become ſeeing hearing taſting nerues like manner nerues conueyed muſcles affoorde vnto voluntary motion together power affoord vnto membrane muſcles fibre determine ſenſe touching ſo commeth paſſe mediation nerues braine bee found euery part body becauſe animall faculty ſeated onely braine doth notwithſtanding transfuſe ſelfe nerues although hath ſaid may eaſily collect vſe nerues yet ſhall amiſſe remember galen ninth chapter fift booke de vſu partium veſalius firſt chapter fourth book make threefold vſes nerues vſe firſt conuay ſenſe vnto inſtruments ſenſation eye tongue eares beſide theſe palmes hand inſides finger yea vppermoſt mouth ſtomack alſo theſe ſence organ ſenſation beſt iudge touching hand mouth ſtomacke hath exquiſite ſenſe want aliment wee commonly call hunger ſecond vſe affoord motion moueable part ſo muſcles inſtruments voluntary motion haue nerues conuayed vnto becauſe made moue whole member therefore nerues great large becauſe ſame muſcles ſtood need faculty diſcerning tactile quality ſecurity preſeruation liues therefore alſo nerues nerues haue faculty ſenſation third vſe part haue nerues wit might perceiue thoſe thing would grecuous vnto although vſe may wel referred former ſo wiſe ſo iuſt ſo skilfull nature ſaith hippocrates wee ſay great god nature ſo prouident behoofe creature ſhe hath diſtributed nerues part although ſame meaſure ſome liberally ſtrayter hand according proportion magnitude dignity action intention remiſsion motion aſsiduity intermiſsion vſes making exquiſite eſtimate neede dignity vſe euery part ſome ſhe hath allowed greater nerues ſome leſſer euery one fitteſt great difference betwixt magnitude nerues thickeſt thoſe diſtributed vnto remoreſt place moſt part ſuch magnitude nerus ſent vnto ioynts becauſe needed greater aboundance ſpirits haue greater proportion original ſinewes granted ſtocke ſpinall marrow rackbones necke loines marrow might receiue competency ſpirits many rootes yet gathered together make one thicke nerue againe though almoſt inſenſibly diſtributed leſſer branch thoſe nerues meane conuayed organ ſenſes head chapter third buoke de hiſtoria animali fourth third de partibus originall animalium diſſection meete nerue produced therefrom thoſe led vnto ſixt coniugation braine ſo ſmall veſalius witneſſeth could finde one great difficulty neyther haue originall eraſiſtratus thought youth dura mater thicke membrane braine ſubſtance already declared doth ſufficiently witnes hippocrates eraſiſtratus wiſer herophilus galen moſt anatomiſts agree braine alſo ſpinall marrow draweth original brain ſay manifeſted wel ſenſe diſſection therof ſee many riuers nerues braine thoſe body continuated alſo becauſe cheſt ſeauenth coniugation tab 23 chara 7 yſſueth vnder ſixt ſpondell necke ſecurity ioyned ſixt coniugation necke firſt ſeauenth coniugation diuiſion cheſt ta 23 ſ chiefe part whereof runneth arme nerues arme produced fift ſixt ſeauenth coniugations necke firſt ſecond cheſt somtime alſo proceedeth coniugation branch making nerue midriffe wherefore ſeeing marrow necke many nerues concur making midriffenerue wonder apoplexy motion midriffe naturall although becauſe obſtruction ventricle braine commonly beleeued animall ſpirit cannot bee conuayed vnto midriffe yet ſeeing cauity ſpinall marrow containeth ſome man breeths apoplexy deale animall ſpirits theſe nerues may tranſported vnto midriffe giue little motion thence reſpiration remaineth though little yet life thereby ſuſtained long animall ſpirit ſhal remaine cauity ſpinal marrow obſtruction ventricle freed apopleticall returneth himſelfe determines life bauhines phyſicke concerning apoplexy cauſe therof wherto though ſort agree yet becauſe handleth way another argument reaſon caſe poſterior branch ſeauenth coniugation tab 24 r alſo leſſe neuer miſsing affordeth ſurcles muſcles lye vpon neck vnto ſquare muſcles cheekes alſo ſurcles ſent fift coniugation braine ſeauen necke excepting onely firſt ſurcles runne according courſe fibre muſcle attaine alſo vnto skinne wonder therefore dogſpaſme greeuous diſeaſe ſeeing muſcle dog ſpaſme doth firſt hand ſuffer conuulſion galen fift chap 13 book de vſu partium archangelus adde 8 coniugation galen veſal eight coniugation iſſuing betwixt ſeauenth eight ſpondell diſtributed eſpecially cubit ell paſſeth chap xxvii nerues cheſt nerues diſſeminated cheſt double well thoſe nerues cheſt paſſe necke ſome take originall braine rather marrow thereof contained scull others marrow paſsing rackbones backe marrow braine proceedeth ſixt coniugation braine runneth cheſt haue partly ſpoken ſay afterward booke ſpinall marrow contained rackes backe iſſue eleuen coniugations twelue coniugations ſaith veſalius bauhine reckoneth twelue egreſſe diuided two branch one greater another leſſe one running forward another reflected backward firſt coniugation tab 23 char 8 veſalius accounteth eight ſpinall firſt coniugation diuiſion marrow iſſueth betwixt ſeauenth rackbone neck firſt cheſt eyther ſide diuided two branch one anterior another poſterior anterior greater hath receiued augmentation ta 23 24 • ſeauenth coniugation ſomtime alſo ſecond cheſt diuerſly commixed neighbour ſinewes attaining vnto armepits diſtributeth propagation tab 24 αα backſide hollow part blade ſo runneth away arme whoſe diſtribution ſhall meete withall place beſides ſendeth alſo another branch tab 23 vnto arme running forward along firſt ribbe ſo top breſt bone beſtoweth bleſsing vppon firſt muſcle cheſt called subclauius conſumed ſpent muſcles take originall toppe breſtbone muſcle called moſtoides sternohyoidei oeſophagaei poſterior branch ta 24 u leſſer reflected vnder booke 34 36 chapter epiglottis eight booke wherefore heere ſhall ſufficient touch vpon thē ſo paſſe vnto reſt follow muſt therefore remember epiglottis nothing elſe griſtle lyeth vppon cleft ſlit larinx made two proceſſes ewre griſtle forme compared luy leafe whoſe baſis broade cone ſharpe baſis vpper inner ſide ſhield griſtle cone vergeth toward pallate griſtle bony would ſo eaſily haue beene depreſſed diglutition readily againe lifted ſelfe vp inſpiration ayer beene fleſhy membranous would indeed haue eaſily fallen ſo readily riſen againe vſe double firſt couer larinx ſwallowing meate organ breathing neceſſary ſhould euer open whether neede take freſh ayer breath old againe organ voyce nothing elſe percuſsion ayre ayer broken ſolid hard light body conſiſteth three griſtles rather arytaenoeides ewregriſtle becauſe like ewre vſe powre water vppon men hand rather hath denomination ſimilitude hath oyle cruiſe firſt anatomiſts accounted griſtle ſingle thoſe haue come ſince haue found double part therof connected knit together membrane ligament indeede theſe part thus ioyned make glottis cleft throttle opening cloſing theſe part make voyce baſe treble epiglottis ſtriketh great ſtroke ſhutteth cleft leſſe columbus ſaith theſe griſtles ſomtimes turne bee bone thus much larinx proceede rough artery weazon becauſe vocall organ wind inſtrument fiſtulated made hollow weazon griſtly griſtle fitteſt inſtrument voyce becauſe middle nature betwixt harde ſoft ſoft thing becauſe weakneſſe doe ſtrike ayer remiſly hard thing doe eaſily ouerturne theſe griſtles like ring round courſe artery branch paſſe whole fleſh lung reaſon theſe griſtles made perfectly circular thinke well ring round gullet ſhould hurt hardneſſe artery alſo might ſwallow freely oftentimes wee ſwallow repaire 18 chapter 6 booke chap iiii griſtles trunke bulke body griſtles bulke body eyther rackbones griſtles spine spine cheſt ſpine many griſtles eſtabliſh articulation ſpondels make motion facile eaſie vertebra necke haue griſtles aboue excepting firſt ſo likewiſe backe loynes thoſe holybone harder drier reſt becauſe whole bone immoueable extremity alſo holybone griſtly called coccyx rump carrieth figure cornet paper wherein grocer vſe put vp spice ſauing cone ſharpe end ſomewhat beaked crooked eſtabliſheth right gut alſo neck womb bladder woman trauel bent backward without great paine cheſt behooued well ſome part ſhould bee griſtly might eaſily follow inſpiration expiration firſt therefore two griſtles griſtles cheſt ioyne clauicles breſtbone sternon breſtbone hath griſtle vpper another lower part vpper part betwixt firſt ſecond bone ſerueth inſtead ligament appeareth able griſtle call xiphoides breſtblade forme griſtle diuers breſtblade alwayes acuminated pointed ſometimes broad end ſometimes tyned diuided two forkes thereupon ſome haue called furcella little forke oftentimes ſaith laurentius haue ſeene round like epiglottis sometime part vnequall leſſer lyeth ouer greater like leafe herbe call horſetongue middle perforated ſmal hole haue obſerued made tranſmit nerue veyne vſe griſtles ſame griſtles hang end bone witte yeelding breake violence outward iniuries defende vſe part ſubiected thereto thinke made defence midriffe place neruous ſome ſafegard mouth ſtomacke hence ſay often come nauſea loathing meate griſtle bent inward preſſeth mouth ſtomacke neotericks new vvriters deride latter vſe becauſe ſay great diſtance betwixt griſtle mouth ſtomacke applyed leaneth vppon backe laurentius ſaith falſe ſuch diſtance liuing body firſt vomit much caſt find paine griſtle againe hippocrates third ſection booke de articulis hath remembred ſuch diſtention ſtomacke forepart ſaith repletion belly meaneth ſtomacke direction broken rib moreouer coacis calleth mouth ſtomacke sternum ſpeaketh bitternes gnawing sternum mouth ſtomack aboue abſurd old wiues fable ſay griſtle ſomtimes fals away may replaced againe muttering peece mattens ouer attrectation groping vppon finally euery rib hath two griſtles one backſide articulated ſpondell another foreſide ioyned breſtbone forward two griſtles rib greater thicker thoſe backward becauſe fore art cheſt diſtended contracted griſtles alſo baſtard rib longer thoſe true rib ſo much griſtles trunke chap v griſtles ioynts almoſt ioint whole body man ſecure facile motion cruſted ouer griſtle partly wee haue ſhewed particular moreouer cauity hollowneſſe shoulderblade nature placed griſtle increaſe ſinus boſome bone leaſt violent motion ioynt ſhould bee eaſily luxed put lower part cubit hath acute ſharpe proceſſe appeareth griſtle filleth vp empty diſtance hindereth hand led cubit ſide frō offending againſt acute proceſſe betwixt sharebones thick hard griſtle ſo vniting together credible ſhold ſeuered time trauell haue ſhewed 33 queſtion fift booke cauity hanches hanchbone another griſtle increaſeth compaſſe boſome cauity therein finally lower head thighes finde two ſemicircular griſtles inlarge lippes cauities word almoſt euery articulation curſted ouer griſtle make motion eaſie ſecure permanent ſo much concerning griſtles proceede vnto ligament ſecond part proces motion head thigh might hindred ligament thigh round becauſe hardneſſe may called ſecond griſtly nerue ſeated cup coxendix ariſeth depth thereof cauity lined ouer fat make head mooue glib brow way third ariſeth outward ankle brace implanted heele helpeth coniunction bone couereth two cauities tranſmit vnder tendon two muſcles called peronaei haue ſhewed hiſtory muſcles vſe theſe ligament wreſt firſt add ſtrength containe tendon muſcles foote mooued place vſe theſe ligament alſo thoſe tendon receiue portion helpe whereof produced lengthned togither ſmal ſtrings nerues like maner lower cockall either legge bone foote firſt thoſe binde talus vnto bone legge common membranous compaſſeth articulation reſt griſtly ſecond ariſeth inſide talus receyued inner ankle inſerted legge bone regardeth talus third ariſeth outſide talus faſtned bracebone regardeth ſame ligament faſten talus bone foote fiue firſt common membranous compaſſeth iuncture talus heele veſalius maketh fift ſecond compaſſeth whole ioynt outſide ariſeth necke talus faſtned bone like boate fourth ſtrong ariſing necke talus implanted bone call dy cube fift ſtrong griſtly ioyneth bone heele vnto cube encompaſſeth ioynt round bone wreſt foote coupled hard griſtly ligament wreſt either among themſelues bone border vpon neighbourbones backſide cube dybone necke talus ſame vnto heele ſo three bone faſtned boatbone foreſide bone afterwriſt ioyned one another vpper part backe foote like manner lower part ſtrong peculiar ligament faſteneth outſide tyeth alſo hindparts bone together becauſe inſinuateth ſelfe among ligament bind faſten particular ioynts toe ioynts finger thus much concerning ligament third part membrane chap xii membrane vſes difference common conſent hippocrates galen almoſt phyſitians 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 membrane coate doe ſignifie one ſame thing knowe ſometimes ſome nice difference amongſt grecian great conſequence therefore would haue vnderſtand meane ſame thing ſpeake coate membrane definition membrane much neceſſary laurentius hath manner ſimilar part cold dry engendred definition membrane ſlimy part ſeede therefore broad thin faſt organe ſenſe touching keeping knitting ſeparating part vnder ſimilar manifeſt becauſe vniforme though wouen fibre yet conſpicuous ſpeake true membrane membranous body ſuch wombe bladder ſtomacke gut ſuch like make part themſelues wherein three ſorts fibre appeare cold dry galen teacheth booke de temperamentis yet leſſe cold dry tendon ligament griſtle bone cold dry artery veines sinewes matter membrane ſlimie part ſeede power heate ſtretched diſtended whence membrane may eaſily dilated compreſſed without danger onely membrane ſaith galen may bee ſafely diſtended contracted therefore part bee diſtended contracted made membranous membrane broad extenſible inueſt preſerue part thight faſt ſtrength beſide may ſo eaſily receiue influxion humor yet thin leaſt waight ſhould offenſiue notwithſtanding though thin appeare ſimple yet euery membrane double thorough duplicature runne veines nouriſhment artery conuey life nerues conuey senſe veſſels ſlender fine fit ſhould conueighed betwixt two coat common office membrane organ senſe touching organe touching eye organ seeing therefore ſenſe membrane moſt exquiſite nerue indeede conueyer ſpirits carrieth downe commandment soule muſcle primary organ motion eye receiueth viſible obiects ſo doth receiue firſt tactiue quality onely membrane muſt eſteeme organ touching deſpoile partes membrane make alſo inſenſible hence fleſh lung liuer ſpleene reſt bowel inſenſible therefore ſenſe touching diffuſed throughout whole body creature becauſe euery neceſſary ſo likewiſe membrane ſprinckled whole body almoſt internally externally outſide body inueſted skinne fleſhy membrane inſide peculiar membrane almoſt infinite obiected galen arte medicinali membrane haue onely inbred obiection influent faculty ſuch ſenſe anſwere reconciler galen ſpeaketh membranous broade ligament iſſue bone three laſt particle definition elegantly expreſſe three principall vſes membrane inueſt part vnder like couering whence haue galen expounded name coates conſerue fibre make fleſh firme ſtable containe ſubſtance part encloſe round leaſt ſhould diſſolue ſeparate part part moreouer faſten one part another whence proceedeth admirable vſes membrane ſimpathy ſociety part perioſtia thou canſt imagine gentle reader ſodainly ſhe forgetteth irkeſome trauell thinke alſo well apaid come within view end tedious voyage alſo haue trauelled worlde thy behoofe iourney haue made many new fourth bone vnto dogtooth ſaith columbus child manifeſt growne body remayneth ſigne footeſtep thereof heereto oppoſeth falopius obſeruations diſagreemēt betwixt falopius col ſaith diſcent ſay ſuture found attaining ōuerthwart vnder pallat dogtooth either ſide child ſhould conſpicuous growne body obliterated finde ſaith diuiſion rifte rather ſuture becauſe doth ſeparate one bone another appear outſide kind articulation ioyne one bone another moreouer cannot bee perſwaded diuiſion ſuch conſpicuous child growne body finde ſeldome obliterated verie old men thus farre falopius bauhine addeth although men doe diuide bone throughout yet dog ape hog doth creature doth diuide fourth bone palat alſo outſide ſorepart iaw chap x bone vpper iaw vpper iaw doth conſiſt one bone many make fitter fiftly ſay hippocrates 18 aphoriſme fift ſection diſtinguiſheth bone ſaith cold thing enemy teeth bone nerues finally ſay ſtone conſume fleſh called therefore sarcophagus within forty dayes deuoure teeth bone ſaith galen cannot referred ſimilar part therfore placeth teeth vnder common genus bone rather becauſe quality matter agree hardneſſe ſolidity ſmoothnes whiteneſſe c yet ſome difference betwixt bone among bone none theſe haue exquiſite ſence becauſe teeth alone admit nerues cauitie teeth alone increaſe life increaſeth without detriment might performe office worne chewing meates increaſed againe onely ſo much worne away otherwiſe would ſoone fayle bone haue ſence obſcure neither increaſe alwayes come vnto ſtate perfection make ſtay becauſe changed performance function differ alſo bone becauſe naked hauing perioſtion without thē would payned wearing hence ariſtotle doth oftentimes differ bone number teeth among bone ſometimes faith bony ſomtimes reſemble nature bone truly compaſſeth eaten away eyther grow looſe fall ſo ioyned synſarcoſis hence may gather articulation teeth gomphoſis mortize 1 way mortize kind coarticulation yet galen doubteth hereof ſaith compoſition therefore grecian call 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 theſe shearer moſt part foure thoſe two next dog teeth leſſe ſhorter dogtooth ta 11 fig 3 char 2 gorreus ſayth foure ſome men ſtead theſe foure either yeare age two grewe vp within part theſe teeth ſtandeth without gummes narrower betwixt baſis ſides behind thicker growing thinne broad degree vnto extremity eſpecially ſo vpper two called duales tab 11 fig 3 char 3 ariſtotle galen 〈 nonlatin alphabet 〉 ſo much figure becauſe ſtand gummes dogtooth dog teeth vſe dog ſhreading teeth two kindes ſharpe teeth ſtanding outward others triangular forme man dogtooth differeth onely two iaw becauſe man mild 2 iaw ciuill creature whoſe ſtrength conſiſteth wiſedome fortitude bodye therefore full dogtooth furious rauening creature breake hard two narrower ſo ſharpe alſo harder thing chance come betwixt teeth ſhearers cannot diuide theſe may breake ſhredders made cut meate ſhort theſe breake hard root thoſe ſhearers ſingle yet infixed deeper growe vp man beginneth wiſe ariſe fourth septenary 28 yeare old time men ſhould temperat moderate breeding theſe teeth ſometime great torment paine therefore auicen calleth teeth senſe ſpring vppe incurued extremtties doe touch others running situation foure wayes end moſt diſioyned theſe drawing teeth ſometimes broken put man cruell torment three root eſpecially vpper iaw one runneth inward two outward conclude commonly two vpper grinder next dogtooth faſtned ſockets two root three three sometimes fift hath foure rare againe two lower grinder next dog teeth haue one roote three others two thoſe teeth call genuini teeth wiſedome haue ſhort rootes partly becauſe portion iaw wil admit deepe inſertion partly becauſe leuigation chewing meate ſo much vſe reſt wherefore rootes grinding teeth lower iaw fewer ſhorter thoſe vpper becauſe ſubſtance lower iaw harder ſolid therefore better able ſtrongly containe teeth beare waight vpper iaw rare ſoft wherein teeth hang therefore ſubiect fall owne weight rootes longer better faſten needed tie binde containe within iaw hence rootes ſhorter teeth drawne leſſe danger labour many eſpecially rootes grow vnto ſockets rootes teeth perforated
